reviewText:
Daedalic is no LucasArts, not being backed by some insanely popular moneymaking franchises that rhyme with Mar Bars or Diana Clones. But the LucasArts we knew isn’t coming back, so I suspect it’s a good try it if you’ve got a hankering for that style of gameplay (with a similar amount of difficulty).

In contrast to its clear inspirations found in series such as Monkey Island, it suffers from production iffiness issues such as variable voice acting and animation quality (in the English version, there are some nasty translation-isms throughout, and multiple lines of that sort where they clearly stressed a word in a sentence that wasn’t the one that should have been stressed), as well as an indecisiveness as to what constitutes an appropriate style of fourth-wall breaking.

Much to the game’s credit, however, the setting is a unique junkyard world and the protagonist Rufus (at least at the start) is more the sort of guy you might expect a point-and-click adventure game kleptomaniac vandal to be: a near-irredeemable jerk. Unfortunately, people are all too willing to point this out to his face, which sometimes works in the story’s favor and sometimes doesn’t. Moreover, there are a lot of artistic details in the world that you simply can’t click on and have Rufus snark about, which is something of a must to get a real feel for an adventure game world’s presence.

One thing that is much nicer than typical old-school examples is that you don’t have to do the pixel-hunting if you don’t want to (hold space to see the interactive spots), and most of the time, you don’t have to watch a slow walk animation just to explore the map (double-click to fast forward through navigational arrows).

Finally, the game is kind of crashy in a few spots (at least the Mac version is), so you may want to do some saving on top of the auto-saving. Some achievements are skippable, but at least one achievement guide in the Steam community is relatively spoiler free.

For all its flaws, the game is usually about as funny as it thinks it is, so at least I can say I enjoyed it. Nonetheless, this game has some mature humor, so don’t get too fooled by the cutesy noseless art; it’s not really for kids.

Droggeljug.

reviewText:
A point-to-click adventure game in 2D environment with comic style characters that utilizes ridiculously humourous dialogues; which is why its so fun to play!!

Its all about a bold, stubborn and egocentric boy called Rufus who listens to no one but his own thoughts. The only thing he wants is to leave Deponia- planet of junkyard and to go to Elysium which is a floating city above the planet that holds all the beauty and wealth.
Everyone, including his close friends tell him he is a maniac and can never succeed in his stupid plans of leaving deponia. But as the attractive lady called Goal from higher sector falls into the trash heaps of deponia and she needs to go back; Rufus assumes that helping her and taking her back to her fiancé would be his only salvation.

Some characters are weird, some are cranky and grumpy but all are really full of amusement. Most of the ideas that Rufus gets to escape from junkyard is by talking to different kind of people that show less politeness and more of a sarcasm. Most of the dialogues are often packed with lot of humor which will make you laugh out loud. The voice acting is top notch which is why i found the game really amusing and didn't stop playing.

The puzzles in the game were quite difficult(especially for me). Rufus has to collect weird stuff in his inventory; combining some of them together to make them work and to proceed his mission of leaving deponia. Finding the right tools and items was a difficult task.

Backgrounds are colourful that even the whole junk and heaps of trashs seems to hold beauty in them.

In the end i want to say i loved this game a lot. It has unusual love story. I recommend this game, even to those who are not fan of such games. But you should try something different, as different is sometimes cool!

reviewText: Let me start off by saying that I am new to point-and-click games. I bought the Deponia trilogy when it went on sale for $14  on greenmangaming. Worth? I think so. I really liked the story because it has it's funny moments. But I suppose because I am new to this genre, I would often find myself stuck and wondering what do next. If it wasn't for online walkthroughs I would never have completed this game. But after completing it with much help, I'm glad I picked it up. It was fun, memorable, and something that I am not used to playing. I suppose trying something new was what made this game refreshing for me.  I would recommend it for that reason alone. Buy if on sale.

reviewText:
One of my favorite adventure games from the last few years due to its fairly quirky nature and its original characters. It also has a very beautiful and charming art style and great music and voice acting to go along with it. The humor is great...most of the time, and the puzzles make sense most of the time but every now and again it goes full on Monkey Island-logic, and you need to think way outside the box to progress.

The game has a lot of missable achievements so would recommend having either a guide handy or use saves very frequently to avoid more playthroughs then necessary. It also has an achievement for beating the game in its alternate mode that you unlock by beating the game: Droggeljug mode. This will replace all written and voiced dialog with the word Droggeljug along with all the info boxes. While funny for the first few minutes it gets really annoying, and you want to uppercut a kitten.

Time to 100%: 6-8 hours

reviewText:
HUZZAH, THE CHORUS GUYS RULE!

Short Verdict: Must-have for point-and-click fans. Nice humor, interesting story, great puzzles, unique characters, hours of fun!

Overview: Deponia is the first game in the adventure, point-and-click trilogy made by Daedelic. You control Rufus, a self-centered jerk who, more than anything, hates Deponia - some kind of a junkyard planet - and wishes to go to Elysium, following his dad's footsteps. The result is a game full of comedy, awkward moments packed with fun, and even some romance.

Pros:
The interface is really great and easy to navigate
The story is interesting, packed with good quality humor, and you'll probably have lots of fun in the way
Good length for an adventure game
The puzzles are really nice and sober--the game provides you not-too-obvious hints when you interact with the world and they've really hit the perfect mark in this aspect. Also, if you need additional in-game help, you can press space to see the hotspots, which is always good as an option. You probably won't need a guide, if you can deal with just the right amount of frustration that pushes you forward.
Characters are really cool and fun. The main character is embarrassingly annoying, but that allows for some role play"
recommended:
when you try to think like he would as you try to solve the puzzles.
Great voice acting
The 2D graphics are really amazing
The BGM is really awesome--specially the Huzzah songs
The cliffhanger for the next game is just perfect--it closes a chapter really well

reviewText:
9/10 - One of the Best Point and Click Adventure Series!

I waited so long to play this game and I regret that! It's one of the best point and click adventures I've played in a while; so good that I'm sure I will complete the remaining 3 games in the series. The story is fun and entertaining and the puzzles, objectives, voiced actors and graphics really put this game at the top.

The story takes place on the world of Deponia; a futuristic world that has turned into a floating garbage dump. You are tasked with helping Rufus get the girl, save the world and get off that dump Deponia! Never EVER pay $20 for this game! If I didn't know any better I would have said it's worth the price... because it is. However, this game is on sale for 90% off literally 8 months out of the year. You can grab the whole bundle for about $4!

Worth $2-3; Great game but bundle is on sale for 90% all the time!

reviewText: Judging superficially, I should love this game. The art design is good, the sound design and voice acting is fine. Overall it's competently implemented and predictable from the perspective of a mid-age mouse-centric adventure, like say Monkey Island 3. But there are a couple of problems.\n\nThe easy one is the mechanics. I've been spoiled by more recent adventures like Broken Age that provide sensible shortcuts for getting around, such as running or warping across screens. None of those are present here, which means watching the protagonist Rufus amble infuriatingly slowly across the map. And you'll be doing a lot of that, because the puzzles are often of the logic-free, lateral-thinking"
date: try-everything-with-everything-else variety that have thankfully become less fashionable these days. The walking in particular annoyed me more than other older games I've been playing such as Broken Sword. How did they manage to be worse than adventure games from almost twenty years ago? Not sure. In any case

reviewText:
Highly recommended for those who are achievement ♥♥♥♥♥s. You can get every single one of them through the game, just remind yourself to check the game's guide to make sure how to get some secret ones.

If you like point-and-click game, be sure to play Deponia, you won't be disappointed. Since I normally don't get the feeling of 'adventure' from some point-and-click games other than 'boring'; I did get it from Deponia. The art, the voice acting and the animation are fascinated, making the game more enjoyable. I didn't skip the cut scenes even once. The story and the characters are well designed. I enjoyed the story so much that I played them right away after I bought the game, non-stop through the end. The main character is a complete jerk, but also an opposite somehow, and that's why he's the most interesting one. There are also mini games which are fun to solve. And how you can combine items you find through the story is freakin' cool. Of how cool it is, I just can't spoil you unless you play it yourself.

Plus, you will be surprised how Deponia, the planet covered in trashes, can create such an environment you'll grow to love.

reviewText:
Short Review: Deponia is a fun Point-and-Click adventure that excells at everything it aims at. As most of these games are 100% about the story, you certainly wont be disapointed with this one as its one of it's strongest features. Long story-short: It's a must for any fan of the genre and a good choice if you're just looking for something different overall.

PROS: Excellent Cartoon-ish, almost Penny Arcade style of Graphics. Every background and character is so rich in colors and every screen was amazingly crafted.
Top notch voice acting. They really put time and effort into this one,
Great mix of both Dry and Dark humour. There's plenty of scenes that will just make you laugh out loud.
Simple interface and overall user-friendly game mechanics. It doesn't punish you if you happen to be completely new to the genre.
Difficulty it's just on the spot. What most of these Point-and-click graphic adventures fail at is the crazy amount of times it just leaves the player blocked at a certain puzzle or scene, which just unables him of advancing the story. I found myself completing Deponia without hitting many roadblocks. There's always a tip or two hidden in the description and the game gives you the option of just Skiping the Hard Puzzles and advancing.
Even though this is a trilogy, there's still a few good hours worth of game here, which is always good.
The Soundtrack is catchy, specially the Bard cutscenes. HUZZAH

reviewText:
A Review of the Deponia Trilogy as a whole:

More info on BrokenCartridge:  http://www.brokencartridge.net/deponia-trlogy-a-retrospective/

Score: 4.5/5

I will not be covering the story in complete detail because there is a lot you should experience on your own while playing through the game. The story in a brief few sentences is that you play as Rufus, an egocentric self-centered slob whose only goal is to leave his trash heap of a planet to go to the city in the sky.  The world that he lives on is called Deponia, a planet littered with trash. All of the rich folk moved up into the city in the sky, Elysium some time ago. During one of your endeavors you knock an Elysium girl off of an Organon cruiser. Throughout the first game you try to use her to find your way onto Elysium, only to end up finding out that the Elysians plan on blowing up Deponia! The second and third games are mainly spent trying to stop the Organon from doing this devilish deed while figuring out their motives along the way.

The story is a very big part of the game, which is why I only covered the basics. The series itself does not like to stray too far off of what is expected from a point-and-click game. As great as that is, if you are looking for an innovation in the genre, you might not find that here. Here, you will find a wacky and hilarious adventure that is dependent on the silly world and narrative. If you already enjoy point-and-clicks, you are in for an incredible treat. Besides the awesome narrative and dialogue, we have a lot of things that set the Deponia trilogy above the rest. The game universe in general is surreal and charming; nothing really comes close to its style in my opinion. You will be surprised how much a planet covered in trash can mesmerize you with its environments.

The trilogy gets better as it goes on. While the first game is great, everything just seems to improve with each one. The story makes unexpected yet oh so juicy turns and twists, increased amounts of detailed environments, an increasing diverse cast, and becomes one of my favorite game soundtracks of all time. The amount of information to tie up the trilogy in the third game alone will leave you with your jaw dropped to the floor. Then include that the second and third both have their own unique mechanics that make them much more puzzling, but so much cooler. One of the best things is seeing Rufus evolve as a character. It is incredibly rewarding to see everything come together.

My only sense of bitterness goes towards the ending. Before I go more into it, I am not saying the ending is bad. If anything it is awesome and leaves a lot for you to speculate and imagine. However, in this particular story, it wasn’t what I was hoping for.  There is so much I wanted to see and experience that was sort of thrown up into the air and left for you to speculate. It is not fair to spoil it, so I won’t. It just left me eager to know more, yet knowing the sad information that this is intended to only be a trilogy. Of course the possibility of a fourth game is always possible, but it isn’t intended. With that being said, I am personally dissatisfied with the ending. Not for the ending itself, but for the thing it did not answer. Good thing Daedalic (the developers) have made many more amazing games to sink my teeth into while getting over it.

That is all you need to know about Deponia before poking your head in. This is a must own for any people interested in adventure games. Daedlic is truly becoming today’s Lucas Arts, and now is a better time than ever to find out why by trying out this trilogy.

reviewText:
Deponia is an adventure game that's a bit difficult to describe.  It has great art, decent writing, some very creative characters, and a pretty interesting story.  The writing and voice acting definitely isn't the best I've seen, but it gets the job done.  The game has a very clean interface, letting you access your inventory with the mouse wheel and providing interact and inspect functions on different mouse buttons.  It's also significantly longer than most adventure games I've played as my playthrough clocked in at around 10 hours.

The one off-putting thing about the game is that you play as an idiot who frequently causes havok around town and everybody hates.  It's a really odd position to be in though the character is quite interesting and is responsible for most of the humor in the game.

The puzzles can get overwhelming at points with tons of items piling up in your inventory with little clue about how to use them though the game keeps it mostly reasonable.

I did run into a very frequent bug where the dialog options window was misaligned, sometimes dropping options off the bottom of the screen, but it never impeded the game.  There were also one or two occasions where certain subtitles were displayed in German.

Deponia is definitely a good game and stands by itself, though it is designed as a trilogy and buying all three games can be a bit of an investment for adventure games.  If you want good adventure games though, it's probably worth the price.

reviewText: I should like this game. I’m always on board for ye old point-and-click adventure, and Deponia knows it predecessors.  It forgets, however, that their fan base is now living the year 2014.  You know, where annoying manboy protagonists are not at all endearing.  Manboy Rufus is bad enough without his town of whiners. Every character you speak with has to either insult Rufus or recall some stupid thing he’s done in the past. Everyone.  I put two hours in before I found a kernel of a plot that didn’t involve someone proclaiming Rufus as a failure or the ginger-haired damsel in distress that fell from the sky. Her name is Goal, by the way, and, she’s spent most of my playthrough unconscious. Rufus claims that Goal belongs to him and that he will save her. The only other female character is Rufus’ roommate/ex-girlfriend, who’s your typical, annoying girlfriend that never stops complaining.\n\nThe puzzles are solid, I’ll give it that.  I found a few head scratchers.  I even laughed a couple of times. But, after a few hours of the game, I couldn’t deal with Rufus and his friends.  The story seemed to be circling the disappearance of Rufus’ father, the former mayor that abandoned him years ago. reviewText:
I wanted to like Deponia – I really did, there's lots of great stuff here, but it all falls flat.

To me there are four things that make a great adventure game: A good story, clever puzzles, interesting characters, and an interesting world for those characters to inhabit.

Deponia gets one of those four right. The world of Deponia is interesting. This great junk planet is not only a bit unique, but it is also beautifully rendered. A junk planet full of scrappy, adaptable people should be a great setting for an adventure game, right? Well...right. But that game is not Deponia. Lets take a look at those other three categories...

Story. Can't have a good adventure game without a good story. Unfortunately for Deponia, it didn't ship with a great story. While it starts off well enough, the plot becomes a bit predictable and uninteresting. Some reviewers have even complained about an undercurrent of misogyny in the game. My take? I can certainly see what those reviewers are talking about, but I'm not going to go into that here. Lets just say that there are few women in the game. Of those women: one gets naked, one is unconcious for 90% of the game, and the other is a man. And the unconcious one? Getting her and winning her over is the goal of the game. Her name? Goal. Clever.

Puzzles. Some are good, but most fall into the meh" or unintuitive category. Puzzles don't have to be unintuitive to be wacky or challenging. It's a cheat
date: and a poor one at that.\n\nCharacters...well...they're forgettable. That's not the worst crime though. The worst crime is that the main character - the one you should be made to empathize with (or at least get a good laugh out of) is actually irratating and unlikeable. Rufus
recommended: who is supposed to be a likeable slacker with a sharp wit and an inflated ego often comes off as posessing a grating personality with few likeable qualities. The puns? Bad...in a bad way. A few might be amusing
hoursPlayed: but the rest are either cringeworthy or fall flat.\n\nMy recommendation: Skip it or wait to pick it up in a bundle on the cheap - and only if you're desperate."

reviewText:
[May contain spoilers. Read with caution.]

I don't think I have words to describe this game.

I don't think I am even capable of remotely justifying how much I loved every second of my Deponia playthrough.

This is the kind of game I had been needing for a long time. Not because of its genre. Because of its charm. Its passion and attention to detail. Its... OK, you get the point.

You play as Rufus, a despicable inhabitant of the massive wasteland that is Deponia, and a damn cool character all around. No matter how many messes he has and is still getting into, you will definitely take his side in every confront of the game - because, well, it's him who you're rooting for since the beginning! This, blended with the game's very lively sense of humour and the intelligent puzzles that come along the way, make for an outstanding experience in Rufus' egotistical point of view.

It's difficult not to love Goal. She is adorable even while in her unfortunate damaged status, and becomes even more lovable after waking up and realising what is going on. On a more personal side, perhaps I may have connected her far too much to someone I love - but let's not get that in the way, shall we? At least for now.

Overall, this... game? Wait, scratch that. To classify Deponia as a simple game" is to insult this masterpiece of humour

reviewText:
A cartoon looking point and click adventure game that allows you to take control of Rufus, a dimwit jerk who uses everyone around him without care.

The story starts off slow and begins to pick up a little bit as you reach the middle of the game, but I still found it lacking even 5 hours in. You play as Rufus, a selfish and slightly empty minded tinkerer who wishes only to leave the junkyard he calls home. Well, the planet he lives on is a junkyard.

Did you know if you double click a location you don't have to walk to it? I didn't, you should probably do the tutorial.

I found the characters hard to like and the protagonist even harder to enjoy. He acts like a childish pig and makes for really cringe dialogue when talking to his ex girlfriend. I also found that there was too much highlight on the protagonist, making you fall out of the story every time he opens his mouth.

The puzzles follow little logic, often being very hard to follow and require the use of a walkthrough if you don't want to go insane. I've found many other reviews complain about this problem too, and it really put me off.
I found trying to finish this game was a chore.

It does have neat steampunk graphics that are fun to look at, and silly humour that will give you a little giggle here and there. The music is also pretty decent for an indie game.

Save often, as this game bugs out every so often ending you not being to move or just plain out interact with items.

I got it on sale, and I would recommend avoiding the full price as the game is too short (around 8-10 hours for first playthrough) and has little replayability.

Personal Rating: 2/5

reviewText:
ehhh... mechanically, it's a gorgeously-artistic, excellent point-and-click. with a few flaws.  some of the puzzles are a bit more obscured than it feels they should be, and these tend to crop up when there are dozens of possibilities.  you spend a LOT of time wandering aimlessly when you encounter this.

writing is amusing.  the egomaniac protagonist gives lots of opportunities for humor, and it's lol-worthy surprisingly often.  that said, I couldn't get past the continuous, degrading treatment of every female in the game.  Goal is brainless so she's ogled and manipulated.  old girlfriend is a tropey pain, so she's drugged and manipulated.  they're both targets of many female-only insults through the entire game (there are basically no male equivalents anywhere).
YES, this is almost totally at the hands of a known-egomaniac-jerk (this is the defense in many reviews I've seen), but *that jerk is the protagonist* and you as a player are forced to act these out.  it even portrays this behavior as the norm, not as an obvious character flaw of Rufus's.
add to that the OVERWHELMINGLY male cast (~ 10x more, nearly all with names and significant roles), and that many of the men are basically good people who are not given any personally-degrading treatment, and I really don't see how else you can interpret this side of things.

tl;dr: it's very pretty, well constructed, but good god does it have heavy-handed sexist overtones.  and it sounds like the sequel(s?) are the same or worse.  can we get some women writers at Daedalic?  or playtesters?  the rest of the talent there shouldn't be wasted like this.

reviewText:
Deponia invokes feelings reminiscent of playing those old adventure games from my youth. I played through the game without object highlighting, because only a defeated man makes use of that particular button of cowardice. Visually, Deponia excels. The characters and environments are consistently good throughout the entire game. While the humor does fall flat at times, the overall tone and presentation of the game harkens back to a time I remember with nostalgia. Rufus, the main protagonist in the game, is a deeply flawed character. He’s not a hero, but he’s persistent, goal orientated (haha), and in a weird way, endearing. And the puzzles. Modern adventure gaming, I feel, has become too streamlined and simplistic. Objects in many of the newer games have obvious purposes and the puzzles are too easy. This is not the case with Deponia, at least initially. The first “act” of the game takes place in a town filled with interesting objects to interact with and puzzles whose solutions are not readily apparent, but still approachable.

However, the quality of the puzzles, and to some degree, the game itself, degrades when you progress to the “second” and “third” acts. Certainly, Deponia gets progressively worse, as the environments become more linear, and the puzzles become more of a chore than an engaging game play element. That’s not to say that the more advanced stages lack puzzles that will give you some pause, they just don’t have very many of them. Without spoiling too much, the story and characters seem to suffer the same depreciation in quality to an extent. Furthermore, there’s a mini-game type puzzle at the end of the second portion of the game where I encountered a glitch that would not let me proceed, even though I had the correct solution. Luckily, I received a steam achievement upon configuring the solution, so I was able to overcome this glitch after several repetitions using the same configuration.

Overall, I would recommend Deponia to any fans of old adventure gaming, because many of its more charming elements have their roots in the old titles. I like the environments, puzzles, the artistic direction, and many of the characters. It is not a perfect game, nor is it the best in the genre, but if you can pick it up for half of its retail price, the game is worth looking into if you like point and click adventures.

reviewText:
Writing this after beating the game in offline mode.

I found the aesthetics and mechanics of the game to be pretty good. The art and animations are nice, the setting is pretty interesting and the voice acting is decent.

The puzzles can get on the cryptic side, but I was able to get through all but one of them without looking at a hint. Somebody that is new to, or doesn't really like point-and-click games might have some trouble with them though.

Now for the reasons I don't recommend the game.

First of all, the protagonist is pretty unlikeable. At first his behavior seems like it's being played up for laughs, or that it's a set up for future character development. Eventually you'll realize that nope, He's just a terrible person, and it's not funny.

This is a big problem when often the protagonist is the driving force behind the player getting past puzzles and finishing the game. Maybe this will change in the sequels.

Secondly, this game is pretty unpleasant throughout. There is a lot of sexism, mean-spirited jokes and uncomfortable implications throughout the game, all seemingly in an effort to make the player laugh.

Some people might think I'm being oversensitive about this, but I'm absolutely not. It is there and it is blatant. The fact that none of these jokes are even clever or funny makes it that much worse.

Despite the game being decent art/mechanics wise, I really can't recommend this.

tl;dr
voteText: 38 of 69 people (55%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Deponia sets new standards for the genre, some bad and some good.

Pros: Graphics, Sound, Controls
Cons: Gameplay, Characters, Performance

Deponia's hand-drawn graphics suit the colorful, cluttered setting perfectly and the voice acting is excellent.  The simple controls work well, but perfect controls should be mandatory for any point-and-click game.

However, the gameplay is unfortunately rather standard for the genre with goofy puzzles (wasabi pea on mousetrap to catch toothbrush, duh!).  The main protagonist is completely insufferable and there is some lightly disguised sexism (don't agree? let me switch your brainchip).  Lastly, there are performance and gameplay bugs that shouldn't exist in as simple a game as this.

Perhaps a no-brainer for point-and-click fans but a cluttered mess for most everyone else.

6/10

reviewText:
This was... weird. I mean, it was a good point-and-clicker. The puzzles worked, and were neither totally illogical nor too easy. Probably the only reason I played it through to the end was because the puzzles were compelling. The world-building is very thorough and clever. The story was decent, but predictable, and brought down by the characters. Deponia is a fun setting that deserves a better story and characters happening in it. The one-liners sometimes got a chuckle from me, but...

My two big complaints: First, the main character is not likeable in the least. They tried to write him a sarcastic, misunderstood oddball, but instead he's just a filthy, self-centered, misogynist jerk. He has a few decent one-liners, but he has remarkably few redeeming qualities beyond that. And hanging a lampshade on it by having literally every other character in the game also hate him doesn't actually make it better, and in some ways it makes it worse.
Second, what is with the rampant misogyny? The female protagonist (if you can call her that) is comatose for almost the entire game, and is treated as nothing more than an inconveniently large inventory item for most of it. Heck, one of the early scenes, she's basically being auctioned off (while comatose) by the mayor of the town to the men of the town to do what they like with her, and the major puzzle sequence is how the main character can eliminate his competitors to claim her as his possession. Heck, her name is Goal. She's a prize, not a person, for the entire game. And the only other female character in the game is the stereotypical violent, incessantly nagging ex, entirely one-dimensional, just one sitcom joke about her nagging after another. Is that all women are, Daedalic? Either pliant, helpless, brain-dead prizes to be won or violent nagging shrews? I think you can do better.

Long story short, if clever puzzles and thorough world-building are enough to carry you through a game, go ahead and get/play this one. If you're just really into point-and-click adventure for the sake of a good puzzle (like me), get it on at least 50% discount, and it might be worth your time. Otherwise, I'd pass this one up.

Maybe the sequel will be better.

reviewText: Deponia! This game is breaks all the rules. Without going into too much detail and spoiling the whole thing, I would just like to say that I found myself enjoying a game that I thought I would hate. The opening sequence (not the tutorial) should have been a key indicator of what was about to go down. The humor plays a huge role in this game. Although not outrageously funny, it provided a few chuckles on occasion. The art style is not my favorite, but I also admit that this particular game would not have been as good without that particular style. The puzzles were a key piece to making the game. I did find a few moments throughout the game where I was unsure what to do next. The game is good at letting you know what needs to be done, but not necessarily how it is to be done. Even so, I found a majority of the puzzles had a good balance. They were neither too hard nor too easy and they always seemed have a unique variety to them. Although on the outside the game might seem like a pile of garbage, the game has so much more to offer. The story (not the greatest, but pretty well thought out), the music (you'll see what I mean), the locations (Kuvaq was one of my favorites), the puzzles (probably the best thing about the game) will all transport you to Deponia and unlike Rufus you won't want to leave!\n\nHuzzah
date: you should buy this game!"\n\nCheck out my other point and click adventure reviews on my page!"

reviewText:
Honestly I don't know how I feel about this game. The art style is great but the storyline is lacking, and I just can't stand the main character. I can only play for fifteen minutes at a time before I start to feel like I'm going to punch something. His personality is grating and falls short of witty with few positives to compensate.

As far as gameplay goes, it's fairly good. If you enjoy point and click games then you'll enjoy this one, I guess. There's an undercurrent of misogyny throughout the game, not too big of an issue but it is bothersome at times. The three girls in the entire game consist of an unconcious love interest who's name is Goal (yes, really), a drag queen used for purely comedic effect, and the ex girlfriend, a '♥♥♥♥♥' and several other lovely names who appears nude for no actual reason.

The puzzles aren't too difficult, and while some can be too easy they give you something to do other than wait for your character to walk across screen at the same, slow, unchangeable pace playing fetch.
I bought this game when it was on sale for maybe a dollar or so, and I think it's about worth that. Maximum, $5.
Seriously beautiful artwork though. Well done on that front.

If you'd like to read more reviews from me, join my steam group!

reviewText:
This is as close as I've got in many years to play a quest like in the good ol' days of Lucas Arts. Unfortunately, it doesn't meet expectations. The story is bad, the script is terrible. The dialogue is tiresome, lengthy and not funny. Maybe it's me, I got too old for this stuff. I also dislike all characters, especially Rufus (The guy you play), which is a problem. Had some issues with the way women are portrayed as well.

The quest itself is okay, for the most part I could figure it out by myself. Solvable but not too easy. For some reason it can get really buggy, which is odd for such a simple game that has been out there for the past 3 years.

All in all, I will probably finish it and might even play it's sequels (already got them in a bundle). But I wouldn't recommend myself playing it in the first place.

(*) Edit: Re-played Monkey Island 1 & 2 recently. Still fantastic as it used to be. So it's not me, It's Deponia.
Plus: Didn't manage to make it through Deponia's seconed title.

reviewText:
Nice try. But no cigar.

Let's get the pros out of the way first, there are not many anyway:

Pros
- I actually like the visuals and setting. I don't think the story, the dialogues and the characters are horrible. They are acceptable. Too many people complain about the characters not being likeable. Try living in a junk city for a while, let's see if you will be likeable then. (In fact you can try this IRL)
- It runs with zero bugs/glitches on Linux.

Although I don't hate this game, I don't recommend it for the following reasons:

Cons
- Random puzzles.  Using peas as bait to catch a toothbrush. Fuuuuuuu
- Silly puzzles.  Place detonation marks based on the resemblance of the hats and rooftops. C'mon.
- Because most puzzles are of the two kinds mentioned above, you need to consult walkthrough and it kills all the fun. Instantly and completely.
- Pixel hunting is annoying. This could have been easily solved, just flash clickable stuff if I have been stuck for a few minutes.

I guess we shouldn't expect a Simon the Sorcerer or a Monkey Island anymore. Modern games are so sophisticated and highly stimulating (well, compared to old games), we expect a lot... Wait, still  making coffee with battery acid  is way too silly and not at all funny.

I wanted to know more about the world and the rest of the story, but couldn't get past the slow, clunky gameplay. Perhaps this game is only for the extremely patient.

reviewText:
This is going to be kind of a rambly review because... I... I... don't know. I don't know what to say about Deponia.

It's got some hilarious writing, especially for an adventure game, and I got through most of it without a walkthrough, so those are some good points.

The art in the game is spectacular. Like, really spectacular... until you get to the cutscenes, where they look like strewn-together flash animations. It still looks good enough that I can let it pass.

But... there's something about when the game says it's going to sit down, shut up, and be serious when it feels like something's amiss. The game just... can't be serious. Too much silly stuff is going on.

I really like the way the game presents itself, as sort of a set of 3 open-world-y scenes" where you have to work out the puzzles throughout each scene

reviewText:
I've played the whole Deponia Series and, put simply:

Deponia (1) is good, but a bit short and easy.

Chaos on Deponia (2) is better, takes longer.

Goodbye Deponia (3) is a lot better than both.

The writing is awesome, the dude(s) behind it is(are) brilliant. I can't remember the last time I actualy read every single line of a game, if I ever did. Every single line of 3 games, in this case. Once you get familiar with Rufus, you laugh your whole way through... he is one of the best heroes ever... characters... anti-heroes... imaginary world threats... whatever.

I hate to admit it but I had to read a walkthrough once in Chaos on Deponia and once in Goodbye Deponia because there's one particular situation in each of them that requires unusual solutions, which is great and in my opinion should be all over adventure games... but I couldn't figure them out, and now I hate myself. (Maybe if they ocurred more often we'd be ready for it... I tend to assume the game bugged... but, sadly, no, it didn't)

Other than the dying/permanently screwing up your game that was possible in old Sierra games (although it is possible in one point), I think everything you can hope for in an adventure game is here, specially in Goodbye Deponia. A bit of Day of the Tentacle, some Full-Throttle's-end-like parts, and...

THE MINIGAMES! I almost forgot about them... mini-games, puzzles, call it what you will. Lots of them throughout the series, very creative, very interesting. Daedalic team was really inspired-- those guys are good and they sure put a lot of effort into this stuff.

Another thing is that instead of things declining by the end of the game (series), which I feel happening quite often these days, in the Deponia it ramps up nicely.

It is hard to compare against adventure games' golden age classics such as Indiana Jones and the Fate of Atlantis, Monkey Island 1-2 and Day of the Tentacle-- which in my idealized childhood memory are unbeatable-- but, from the adventure games I've played in the last 15-20 years or so, I'd say the Deponia Series is the best.

Each game has several achievements that, if you want, you will have to go after on purpose. I left several behind, having no idea whatsoever of how to get/how did I miss them but they are there, and you can fry your brain further if you dare chase them all.

Damn... now that I think of it, along with the achievements I probably also missed some good lines...

Last and least, there's a con, which you may not see as one: you can hold the spacebar down to show all interactive spots on the screen. I hate that, it feels like cheating... and it's right there, so easy to use that I end up doing so.

Put shortly, if you like adventure games, I say definitely get this one (these three).

reviewText: Deponia is, at its heart, a love story--a tale of boy meets girl. The boy, Rufus, is a dreamer, the archetypal down-on-his-luck underdog who aims high but fails oh so miserably time and again. The girl, Goal, is classically unobtainable--rich, pampered, spoiled, and blissfully unaware of her own attractiveness to the opposite sex. Oh, and she has a removable chip in her head, lives in a floating palace in the sky, and has the power to blow up the entire planet. No, this isn't the most conventional of love stories, but such wackiness is befitting for a game that is as much about providing oodles of comic relief as it is about telling the tale of two lost souls.

reviewText: Deponia kind of suffers from the adventure-game syndrome of old where you don't actually know what to do to progress the story or solve a puzzle so you wind up going in circles for awhile.  Then once you figure out that you had about half of the solution right but you didn't figure out the rest of it, you'll feel really stupid at not realizing that you were supposed to send a baloon up a chimney and that you spent probably about half an hour before you caved and looked at a walkthrough that made it seem oh-so-obvious.\n\nAdventure games rule.  Pick this up if you like adventure games and their somewhat obtuse solutions.

reviewText:
Love this game. I like the story, the humor, the voice acting, and the artistic style they've used for the graphics. The puzzles aren't too easy. Most of them are not too challenging to the point you just start grinding your teeth. The puzzles aren't bad. I've not come across anything like that horrid rain dance in the Book of Unwritten Tales yet, which is less a puzzle than it is an exercise in frustration. That required you to tap the keys given in a list that scrolls down the screeen. The list speeds up as you go along so if you're terrible at things that require precise timing or have painful arthritis problems in your hands that stiffen your fingers like I do, a puzzle like that can quickly render a game unplayable. Thankfully, there's nothing like that here in Deponia.

Some of the puzzle solutions are obvious so if you like a constant challenge you may be disappointed. What I definitely find aggravating though is that some of the solutions bear no resemblance to logic at all and I found myself seeking hints. There were a couple points where I resorted to walkthroughs because the solutions made no sense whatsoever and I'd have never figured it out in a million years. I've also been tripped up by the related problem of some of the puzzles not using the logical and, to me, obvious answer and like I've mentioned before, using instead an alternate solution that makes no sense. It would be nice if I could use an alternate solution I see instead of being locked into the one the developers thought of.

Still, those are the only drawbacks and while they are occasionally frustrating they haven't ruined the experience for me. I got enough enjoyment out of the game that I still consider this a good purchase and I have no regrets. I enjoyed the story and can't wait to play the other two games in the series.

reviewText:
Short version: 83%The first part of the Deponia trilogy isn’t exactly a bold game that tries to discover new territories in mechanics or storytelling; it’s just a well-constructed point ‘n’ click with proven character concepts, plot mechanics, and puzzles.

Long version:The Deponia series is arguably Daedelic Entertainment’s most famous point and click title. Yet the first instalment, for the most part, is just another good adventure game, nothing more.

The protagonist, Rufus, is a stereotypical egocentric jerk who just wants to achieve his one goal in life (leave his home for good), no matter how much grief it causes to everyone around him. When the other main character, Goal from the (literally) upper society drops into his life, he sees her only as a ticket out… but eventually gets entangled in a much larger plot, which– the game being the first part of a trilogy– naturally ends in a cliffhanger.
What makes this often seen story stereotype work is the writing. The dialogues are perfect from Rufus’ self-centric monologues to the sarcastic responses he gets from everyone else; the characters may be simple, but they have a good synergy.

The puzzles are what one expects from a point ‘n’ click: mostly inventory and map hotspot manipulation, with a few occasional (and skippable) minigames. The difficulty is moderate; if you know how adventure game logic works, you shouldn’t have problems– except for maybe the middle segment, which require some trial and error.

As a final word: the trilogy was re-released as a single game, making these individual titles somewhat obsolete… unless you want to play the famous drugglejug mode, which was never implemented in the Complete Edition.

reviewText:
I picked up Deponia based on the trailer vids, lovely art style, and excellent music. The first chapter was quite enjoyable, with some clever puzzles that got you thinking outside the box.

By the third chapter, what had started as a few stereotypical gags was now a blatant streak of misogyny underlying the whole game. As the puzzles descended into opaque trial and error, I was counting on a good story with interesting or at least growing characters to pull me along. Instead the game delivered more woman bashing (as in literally bashing an unconscious woman into things). I had to turn it off.

Then I went and read what others were saying about the game, and I'm glad I stopped when I did, because the series keeps getting uglier: http://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2013/11/11/wot-i-think-goodbye-deponia/

I regret the hours I sunk into this game, and that by buying the game I gave support to this kind of hateful content. Daedalic are clearly extremely skilled creators, but until their design and writing grow up a bit I won't be buying another of their games.

reviewText: Summary: Deponia is a fast-paced comedy of errors and one of the most unusual love stories in gaming history. The twist-filled story takes its off-beat characters all over trash planet Deponia, a unique game world in the style of Douglas Adams, Terry Pratchett and Matt Groening. From Kuvaq, an improvised village built inside a giant trash heap, to the swimming black market and the dark corners of the elevated planetary railways: Deponia is brought to life with detailed hand-painted backgrounds in widescreen format and top-quality cartoon animation. 8/10

reviewText:
Disclaimer: This is just for people who don't play Adventure games and are trying to get into them.

I don't think this one will help you. It didn't help me.

I don't usually play adventure games but when I do ... I don't.

I was really looking forward to Deponia. Because of the graphic style and because of the humor. And it was fun at first.

BUT: Then came the Adventuring part. Taking everything you see, trying to combine it and somehow figure out how to use something on something else. At first I've tried to figure everything by myself. Later I've started to look at the guide, here and there. And after a while I've found myself looking at it more or less constantly. Those things just don't make any sense to me. I don't know why would I knock out a parrot with laughing gas and I don't know what I would do with him afterwards.

I don't doubt that Deponia is a great game. For people who like adventure games. But if you don't like adventure games, Deponia isn't for you despite how gorgeous it looks, how funny it can be, and how great the voice acting is.

I'm really sad that I couldn't enjoy it. But I won't play game by reading a guide.

reviewText: I am huge fan of Monkey Island, and this is the first game I've found that comes close. It has good humour, nice exploration and beautiful illustrative artwork (think MI3). Downsides are that you're launched straight into a tutorial, rather than given time to watch the scene be set; in addition, the voice recordings aren't great in that a) the artists haven't received full direction, so sometimes they stress the wrong word and ruin the joke, and b) there isn't enough variety in responses. The game is also fairly short but is actually a lot longer than most, and definitely longer than your average Indie game. In all, really, really good. Enough to make me buy the sequel :)

reviewText:
Deponia aims to be quirky to sets itself apart from many of its kind. It has however fail in many different aspects:

1. Characters: In a story-driven game such as this, the characters are far from memorable. Each one seems to try its upmost effort to sound sarcastic, cynical or downright idiotic to an extent that it fails to deliver an exciting blend of characters. Don’t get me wrong, I love characters that make a fool of themselves (e.g. Rincewind from Discworld) but what Rufus tried to portray feels way too forced. Instead of the light, bite-sized comedy pieces that I was expecting, I witnessed sloppy production and narrations. Granted, there were some funny moments, but it is difficult to give proper credit given the rarity of such occasion.

2. Puzzle: Again, another essential element to a point-and-click game. This is the major flaw of the game. I give huge leeway to such games where logic and questionable detours need to be taken or when pesky puzzle elements are involved that somehow blocks the progress of the game simply to discover that it makes little sense. Deponia is King of this behaviour right here.

3. Artwork: Despite the fact that I am not a fan of this kind of artwork, I must say this is where Deponia shines the most, the artwork of its kind is downright stunning, exuding a very unique feel towards the world of Deponia.

4. Music: Passable music, though there are some memorable ones. This, together with artwork, ensures a great thematic feel of its kind.

Problems: As of 11th May 2013 a bug exists in the middle of the game where you will be stuck and unable to continue. I find this very mind-boggling that such a bug could have existed until now. This needs immediate repair.

Overall, if you're a fan of point and click game, this game might be worth it, otherwise, stay clear away.

reviewText:
Deponia is the 1st part of a Trilogy that takes you to the junkyard world of Deponia where the stubborn, egocentric and yet bold boy Rufus dreams of leaving the tedious Deponia for the paradise Elysium seen floating in the sky above. For me the games biggest strength have to be it´s quite humorous tone which is especially notable in the often hillarious dialogues filled with sarcasm. It should be noted that the main protagonist Rufus is not a very likeable character, he´s actually an excellent example of the 'anti-hero', which might put some people of but I myself found it refereshing to play as a flawed character instead of the usual Paragon.

The graphics and especially the backgrounds are really nice and the character models are not far behind. The Audio is excellent and especially the Bard theme during some of the cutscenes. The puzzles are varied in difficulty which I like but all those who where tougher to crack had some form hints often found in dialouges with characters nearby. The puzzles also have a 'skip' option for those who find them annoying and want to get on with the story which is nice I guess.

One final notice is that the 'silly mode' called Droggeljug which is needed in order to get the final achievement for 100 % is super annoying and I would actually go against my usual view and recommend to 'cheat' in order to get it. Having to play another full playtrough with no dialouges in a game based on dialogue was not a very bright idea by Daedalic in my opinion but it´s a minor flaw in a otherwise great game.

I fully recommend buying this although the full price of 19,99 € might be a tad to much considering the lack of replayability but at a -50 % or better discount it´s definatly a good buy.

This is the first part, out of a 3 part adventure story, where the main character is Rufus, a pathologically egotistical individual, that wants to escape from a planet that is now all filled with junk. reviewText:
A decent entry in the point-and-click genre. I'd recommend getting Deponia on sale, though, considering the amount of gameplay. I consider the replayability to be a bit low, considering there are not multiple possibilities and you've already figured out the puzzles. A few pros and cons:

+ I thought that the story behind the world of Deponia was fairly interesting.
+ Rufus grew on me by the end, despite his obvious flaws.
+ Good style and gameplay.

- A lot of the puzzles were counter-intuitive to me, and I did reference a walkthrough quite a bit while playing.
- No well-developed female characters.
- A bug with the inventory button disappearing forced me to play with a mouse instead of just my trackpad.

reviewText:
Where to start?

With a lot of point and click adventure games, getting stuck is just part of the process and peeking at a walkthrough is fairly standard. The person making it is trying to be witty, creative, yet logical at the same time with the item combinations and just miss by a long shot.
I’m fairly sure any point and click adventure fan has had this from time to time. There is always a moment or two you ask yourself… “Well, how was I seriously supposed to figure out that you had to put the chicken in the blender to get egg yolk, use that yolk with a daisy to make a cake, eat the cake and fart out the key to why I’m stuck.”
My point being, the solutions aren’t always as obvious as they might think. I was very glad to find that Deponia isn’t like that. It’s consistently logically throughout the whole game.
Admittedly, I did get stuck a few times, but it was more of a “how DIDN’T I get that?” rather than a “how did they think that made sense?”

The Art style in Deponia is beautiful. A planet consisting of junk has never looked so good.
The animation, music, voice acting and humour are all great to. There is a real charm about the characters and the little witty things that they say, that makes this game all that much more enjoyable. Which, talking of voice acting, reminds me…

Droggeljug mode!

I finished this game, looked back on the achievements I had left to get and I thought…
…This is going to be interesting.

Well, I never knew that Droggeljug mode would be as painful as it was. Finishing the game unlocks a new mode, where everything and anything that anyone says ever, comes out: “Droggeljug!”
Now this is amusing all of a 10 second period, but after that it is quite painful. They say it in the same tone of voice every time. You may get the odd “Droggeljug?”, but apart from that it is fairly robotic. That being said it was still a funny little thing that they added which I thought was quite unique.
I can imagine that this mode would make it a lot more challenging to play through if I didn’t literally just finish the game and still have everything fresh in my mind. Due to parts in the story where you need to note where the chat options are to get what you want off of them. (E.g. a character quiz’s you before they’ll give you a key, and all you have is a list of Droggeljugs for answers)
It’s a challenging achievement, but a fun one. Despite that a lot of people probably muted it because the noise drove them crazy, I left it on low. Just to keep reminding me how ridiculous what I was doing really was.

All in all, I love this game, it’s great. I can’t wait to start the next part in the story.


TL;DR : Logical item combinations, engaging story, great humour, wonderful art and definitely a must have for any point and click adventure game lover.

reviewText: Point and click adventure game in my opinion stand on three pillars as a genre, narrative, game aesthetics and the puzzle complexity. If any of these pillars suffers it could entirely break the game and make a bland if not a terrible experience. This is what happened in Deponia with its narrative that just utterly failed the game's mostly good puzzle and aesthetic design. I just found that I was never engaged with the protagonist or the overall narrative which lead me to simply turn off the game on multiple occasions because I just got bored of the entire affair. The worst part was that even when I finally did finish the game I was given that utterly vapid void of an ending that brings closure to nothing and essentially demands that I play the next Deponia game to get a better picture of the narrative, which just isn't going to happen when I couldn't give a rats ♥♥♥ about anything going on to begin with.  I definitely saw the potential in Deponia and I saw the reasons people like it, but I can't in good conscious bring myself to anything other than warn people not to play this game. This is something that I hate to do to game's since I'm a big adherent to the philosophy that a game can be good regardless of how long it is, but for 19.99 a six hour experience just isn't good value for money for the player and that isn't acceptable in my opinion especially when its a mediocre experience at best.\n\nIf you want to read a more detailed review you can find it over here on my blog: http://mouseandcontroller.blogspot.com/2014/07/deponia.html.

reviewText:
Deponia was very interesting experience for me. While I have played point-n-click games previously, it was back when I was in elementary school before I received the original (brick) GameBoy. The settings and graphics were unique while the animation and voice-acting were better than expected.

While I personally could care less about Rufus' (Protagonist/Main Character) attitude and personality, I will admit that this game did have me laughing at some points due to the pitfalls he encountered. Yes, his comebacks are terrible and oft a pun, but the storyline kept me interested enough to continue playing to see how things panned out.

The first playthrough took about eight to nine hours to complete. The second one was quicker though challenging since I enabled Droggeljug" effect (turn off your speech sound lest you go nuts from hearing it so much) and had to guess often as to which response I was clicking on.

All-in-all
recommended: with a note to just play it for humor. One game/chapter done

reviewText:
I grew up on the Police Quest/Space Quest/Sam & Max/Monkey Island/etc (Lucas Arts and Sierra), and having played the game Memoria from this studio a few months ago, I was looking forward to Deponia.

I find myself disappointed.

I have no problem with a game having an anti-hero character, but this main character is a twit. He does show character growth through the game, but it's only realized in the ending. Maybe. Most of the game he is just really a jerk in a way that's obivously meant to be over the top and slap stick, but wears out its welcome pretty quickly. I am going to try the sequel - I am  hopeful that the main character does improve.

I would NOT recommend this game for someone trying out adventure games for the first time, or trying them again after a time away. It's not that this is a bad game - it's very solid in many aspects - but that main character is going to be very off-putting to some people.

reviewText:
Deponia is a good little point and click adventure game. It has its share of tedious puzzles but most of them are good and makes sense (not a la Discworld). The story is good enough although very linear (we can argue a story is always linear :p ) in my opinion. We are far from games or stories such as the Longest Journey or Monkey Island.

The recommended inventory system using the mouse wheel is extremely good and works very well, you can also hit the space bar at anytime to highlight every clickable objects in an area and the hand drawn graphics are really fantastic.

I noticed a few bugs here and there, some of the clickable objects would eventually become non-clickable, and sometimes, the dialogue options are sometime off screen (probably not optimized for my resolution ?). The dialogues are well written and the actors did a great work in my opinion but the sound is not normalized very well making it sometime an inaudible mess.

Finally, I want to mention that Rufus (the hero) goofiness only worked halfway for me. He is very one dimensional and his lines became very repetitive quickly. Some other characters such as Toni, Kuvac's mayor or Lotti are just more interesting making the world of Deponia a very believable one.

If you can go through all the above, then yes, I think you will like Deponia.

reviewText:
If you're looking at this game when it's going for 2$ get the damn game. If it's going for 20$ as usual... maybe only if you're really into point-and-click games, and have tried other ones. It's a solid enough buy nonetheless. (just my opinion)

A fantastic game with a unique cast of characters and beautifully drawn sceneries. The story itself, beneath the cartoonish appearance, was actually quite intriguing and compelling at times, though admittedly hindered by tedious game pacing (a good example being spending easily 30+ minutes simply making a espresso.). Playing while reading a walkthrough is probably a good idea unless you intend to be in it for the long haul.

The voice acting I particularly enjoyed; I did notice it did not always sync (particularly in the earlier parts of the game), something which bothered me- but it was nonetheless enjoyable to listen to the voiced dialogue anyways. Even for supporting" characters I found the voice acting to be rather spot-on.

Content-wise the game seemed rather sparse
date: but it was consistently enjoyable from beginning to end."

reviewText:
'Deponia' is a humorous point and click adventure, which is near to 'The Books of Unwritten Tales' where you can feel the world and want to be part of it. *Hussa!*

Desc:
You play as 'Rufus' who is a egomaniac, prides himself on being the best and who wants to leave his scrap home planet Deponia to Elysium with a vengeance. On his mission he meets 'Goal' the love of his life. He is willing to do everything for her to win her heart AND to get to Elysium.

Pros:
+ Really nice painted graphics and animations
+ Strong audio speakers
+ Funny as hell (sometimes very rude humor)
+ Tutorial is available
+ Skippable mini-games
+ References to previous Daedalic games
+ Demo available
(+ Sequels for continuing fun)
(+ Achievements [easy to collect] )

Cons:
- Annoying Droggeljug achievement (no shortcut)

Recommended, even if it's not on sale, because of the great story and the awesome trappings playing on a planet/world full of scrap.

9/10

reviewText: Πρόκειται για ένα φανταστικό adventure game, που ενσωματώνει ορισμένους πολύ επιτυχημένους γρίφους που απαιτούν καλή σκέψη και συγχρόνως διαθέτει μία όμορφη ιστορία, εξελισσόμενη σε έναν κόσμο διαφορετικό εκείνων που μας δίνουν τα περισσότερα παιχνίδια. reviewText:
Yay, after many years, I get to play another humor adventure game. So how does Deponia measure up?

To begin with I very much like the art style. It's got 2D fully animated characters with some pretty nice painted backgrounds. Everything's easy to move around and interact with. Thankfully you can double click to instant-move to a location.

Music is serviceable. I like to think of it as elevator music. It's there, and you notice it, but it won't stick, may irritate after a while, and you'd probably rather listen to your own music.

The story is all right. The main character is perhaps a little too genuinely self-centered, but he gets better... somewhat... I think...

The game's humor falls a bit on the flat side, which is a shame. I don't think I had a laugh out loud moment, just some grins here and there. I was willing to ignore it though, in order to find out what happens next. I admit I'm more than curious as to what is going on with Elysian physiology, but that wasn't answered in the first game, so I guess I'll have to play through the next (two?).

Now for the meat and potatoes of the game - the puzzles. This is where I feel the game was lacking. There are several areas where you are just bombarded with random items you pick up, and very poor clues as to where to go or what to do. Ordinarily I do my best to avoid guides, but I ended up using one for this game. It didn't even feel rewarding for the stuff I DID manage to figure out on my own.

I guess I'd rate this game a 7/10. It's no King's Quest, it's certainly no Monkey Island.

reviewText:
When I was a kid I played Monkey Island and Indiana Jones and the Fate of Atlantis so when I spotted this game on Steam and saw the fun, easy going attitude I simply couldn't resist it.

You're playing the local celebrity(?) Rufus who's dreaming about reaching Elysium, the city in the sky and, being the genious you are there's nothing that's gonna stop you.

The game got a nice sense of humor that I found very amusing and all the dialogues have voice actors who did a really nice job. In addition to the normal adventure clicker you also get to test your wits in some mini-puzzle games in order to progress (they're optional though so if you're not into that then there's a skip button although you won't get achievement for it).
The controls were easy since they were just point and click, the mouse-pointer showing you the options available and the scroll-down inventory was a nice touch as well.
As far as difficulty goes I'd say it's a little bit easier than the Monkey Island games while still hard enough to keep it interresting.

Cons: Low replay value (since you already know where to go, what to do etc) and I also felt as if the game was a bit short compared to for example the Monkey Island games.

Having trouble deciding weither to give it a 4 or a 3 due to the low replay value but I'm guessing that, based on the genre, nobody really expects that to be high anyway so... *drum roll*... 4 it is!

1 - Crap, don't buy
2 - Fun for an evening
3 - It's an alright game
4 - Great game
5 - One of the best I've ever played

reviewText:
A fun point & click adventure... not quite up to the Lucas Arts glory days, but still fun.

You play as Rufus - oxygen thief pretty much sums him up, but so much so that he ends up being likeable.  The other characters are amusing and the world is interesting - a trash heap planent, a city in the sky & hints of class warfare:  I want to know more, so guess I'm going to have to play the other 2 games in the trilogy.

For the most part, the puzzles make sense.  Where they don't & other characters don't give you helpful hints, you generally have few enough inventory items & interaction options to go through the trial & error grind without having too many murderous thoughts.  A nice touch to bypass any frustrating pixel hunting - pressing the spacebar shows you all the objects you can interact with.

Overall, a nice diversion.  Not going to blow you away, but still worthwhile.

reviewText:
Charming - mostly due to the fantastic artwork.

The obnoxious yet charming Rufus follows your lead to solving puzzles, yet he always turns everything into chaos. I felt engaged with the story of a misfit literally trying to reach the sky, despite the fact that he can be an awful person.

Getting stuck on a problem and wondering around everywhere for a place to interact with items was common. While some solutions are common sense, others are as oddball as Rufus, and puzzle progression (where one solution lends hints toward another) is mostly nonexistant.

If you're interested in point-and-click adventure/puzzles, I suggest Deponia if not only for the artwork and animation.

reviewText:
It has good things and not so good things.

Things that I liked:
- Good looking game, nice art.
- Great music.
- Interesting story, keeps me wanting to see more although it's unfinished...
- Most puzzles are fair, not too hard but also not easy.

Things that annoyed me:
- The protagonist is a jerk. I don't hate him, but he could shut up sometimes, he keeps talking and talking every time you click anything, not alternative short lines when you click a second time, like in every other point 'n' click game.
- The story is unfinished, the ending was really disappointing. And not just for the story, but also because it was rushed and anticlimactic, even the setting was depressing and dull. I already knew there are like 5 or 6 other games, but I thought at least the first one would have a satisfactory ending.
- Every new scene throws too much stuff at you, it's confusing to have to visit like 5 different rooms filled with new stuff when you don't even have a clear idea of your objective. That's bad design and could be done better, just look at other games like Broken Sword or even Monkey Island, much better in that sense.
- BUGS. This wasn't a problem until I got to the end of the game, where it kept crashing and I had to click like 3 or 4 times on a item in the inventory to select it. I ended up playing in windowed mode and it seemed to solve the crashing.


Despite the annoying things I recommend the game, it's fun and the story is interesting, but keep in mind it is NOT finished, so get it on sale and then decide if you want to play the other games.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
This is a cute point-and-click game with a Steampunk flavor.  Like a many p&c games though, the hunt for items to use on other items or locations can, by the end of the game, be more annoying than fun.  I do recommend the game though, as long as you're aware of a few things;

There is dialogue.  A lot of it.  And while you can skip over it, kind of, it's not as easy to skip as in come other games.

The main character walks slowly.  Seriously slowly.  I assume that was meant to be part of his laid-back character but, again, by the end of the game, it gets to be annoying.  There are cuts to different places that you can use but still, he needs to walk some places.  Slowly.

I had a few technical issues. The Inventory link would disappear at random intervals and a couple times the program shut down, with no explanation as to why.  A reload always fixed it though.

Ultimately, the game was fun and I enjoyed it, which is why I recommend it.  The story was engaging as well, so I'll definitely play the sequels.  All in all a nice, relaxing couple of hours.

reviewText: Overall score: 8/10\n\nThis game definitely has been a lot of fun.  The humor in it reminds me a lot of the Space Quest point and click adventure games from the 80's/90's with its silly humor.  It is graphically beautiful for the main stage being a futuristic wasteland that you live in.  Story line is quite humorous and well written.  The only thing that occasionally became annoying is it wasn't always clear on what you are supposed to be doing next to progress forward further into the story.  Definitely requires a lot of out of the box" ways of thinking for some of the puzzles and figuring out how to use the objects you pick up.  For any fanatic of the classic point and click games
date: this will definitely bring you right back to it!"

reviewText:
A much better visual than Primordia, the first thought that sprung in my mind when I first played the game. Excuse me but I need to save my eyes from getting more damage from broken visuals. Graphic looks like to be a hand drawn - my preference really. Sometimes comical style game is alot better than advanced looking AAAs.

Game is a point and click genre - one of my favorite type to do casually in between dota matches or doing serious AAA titles like jumpscare Dead Space series. Game's full with satirical humor that brings lots of facepalm moment. It's not bad, though, in fact I quite enjoy the story and the humor.

Being a point and click, gameplay isn't that complicated. Although yes, this is more expansive than The Walking Dead - despite some elements are the same - but the 'puzzles' are a bit more tedious and ridiculous (helloooooooooo why do I have to capture a hiding fork????). And somewhat frustrating if you're really clueless on what to do. But eh, again, it's pretty much fine since we have walkthrough or videos in all around internet. No big deal.

Overall, to my surprise and initial negative view on the game, this is a pretty much ok title. Too bad this isn't a type that allows you to sit back and enjoy with the controller - the game's much easier to play with MK/B than a gamepad.

reviewText:
Deponia is a good little point and click adventure game. It has its share of tedious puzzles but most of them are good and makes sense (not a la Discworld). The story is good enough although very linear (we can argue a story is always linear :p ) in my opinion. We are far from games or stories such as the Longest Journey or Monkey Island.

The recommended inventory system using the mouse wheel is extremely good and works very well, you can also hit the space bar at anytime to highlight every clickable objects in an area and the hand drawn graphics are really fantastic.

I noticed a few bugs here and there, some of the clickable objects would eventually become non-clickable, and sometimes, the dialogue options are sometime off screen (probably not optimized for my resolution ?). The dialogues are well written and the actors did a great work in my opinion but the sound is not normalized very well making it sometime an inaudible mess.

Finally, I want to mention that Rufus (the hero) goofiness only worked halfway for me. He is very one dimensional and his lines became very repetitive quickly. Some other characters such as Toni, Kuvac's mayor or Lotti are just more interesting making the world of Deponia a very believable one.

If you can go through all the above, then yes, I think you will like Deponia.

reviewText:
If you're looking at this game when it's going for 2$ get the damn game. If it's going for 20$ as usual... maybe only if you're really into point-and-click games, and have tried other ones. It's a solid enough buy nonetheless. (just my opinion)

A fantastic game with a unique cast of characters and beautifully drawn sceneries. The story itself, beneath the cartoonish appearance, was actually quite intriguing and compelling at times, though admittedly hindered by tedious game pacing (a good example being spending easily 30+ minutes simply making a espresso.). Playing while reading a walkthrough is probably a good idea unless you intend to be in it for the long haul.

The voice acting I particularly enjoyed; I did notice it did not always sync (particularly in the earlier parts of the game), something which bothered me- but it was nonetheless enjoyable to listen to the voiced dialogue anyways. Even for supporting" characters I found the voice acting to be rather spot-on.

Content-wise the game seemed rather sparse
date: but it was consistently enjoyable from beginning to end."

reviewText:
Very enjoyable p&c game with good atmosphere and quite a lot of humour.

You play a guy called Rufus trying to get off his boring literally trashy planet and go to the cool-people-place. On his way point&click and puzzles happen.

The puzzles for progress are mostly solvable without the use of a guide, though I did have to look up a few things so I would not have to use every item in my inventory with every useable spot.

All the achievements are gettable on first playthrough if you go full tryhard and read a guide all the time. If you're slightly less tryhard you may want to remember to save your game every once in a while so you don't have to go through entire chapters to get that one last thing you need. One achievement seemed only achievable through downloading a savefile (check forums), at least it wouldn't work for me the proper way and seemed a common problem.

Definitely recommended, at least if purchased on sale, and I will play the other games in the series (when they go on sale).

My one nuisance with this game was after doubleclicking to auto-go to next place, Rufus would take a few seconds to stroll slowly into the screen before I could doubleclick move to next place. Really annoying if you're not sure what you're supposed to do where and check every place because walkthroughs are for uncool people.

Art, sound & voices all good, music is pretty cool, even Rufus thinks so as one of his idle moves is air-guitaring to the currently played music.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
'Deponia' is a humorous point and click adventure, which is near to 'The Books of Unwritten Tales' where you can feel the world and want to be part of it. *Hussa!*

Desc:
You play as 'Rufus' who is a egomaniac, prides himself on being the best and who wants to leave his scrap home planet Deponia to Elysium with a vengeance. On his mission he meets 'Goal' the love of his life. He is willing to do everything for her to win her heart AND to get to Elysium.

Pros:
+ Really nice painted graphics and animations
+ Strong audio speakers
+ Funny as hell (sometimes very rude humor)
+ Tutorial is available
+ Skippable mini-games
+ References to previous Daedalic games
+ Demo available
(+ Sequels for continuing fun)
(+ Achievements [easy to collect] )

Cons:
- Annoying Droggeljug achievement (no shortcut)

Recommended, even if it's not on sale, because of the great story and the awesome trappings playing on a planet/world full of scrap.

9/10

reviewText:
Charming - mostly due to the fantastic artwork.

The obnoxious yet charming Rufus follows your lead to solving puzzles, yet he always turns everything into chaos. I felt engaged with the story of a misfit literally trying to reach the sky, despite the fact that he can be an awful person.

Getting stuck on a problem and wondering around everywhere for a place to interact with items was common. While some solutions are common sense, others are as oddball as Rufus, and puzzle progression (where one solution lends hints toward another) is mostly nonexistant.

If you're interested in point-and-click adventure/puzzles, I suggest Deponia if not only for the artwork and animation.
