reviewText:
I can understand many of the points presented here. The pacing definitely is a bit off, and I completely agree about Kuvaq: They gave you the impression that it’s “just one more puzzle and then we can escape” the whole time, and that is kind of frustrating.

What I absolutely can’t understand is that story, dialogue, animation and humour are being criticised. Those are the strong points of the game that actually make it one of the best classical adventure games I’ve played in a long time. The cutscenes are top notch and beautiful to look at, the characters are quirky and funny and just thinking of the scenes with the post robot going crazy on bubble wrap or the doctor “transforming” into a police officer makes me chuckle.

The story was also misinterpreted, I think. Rufus actually is a pretty selfish guy, and you can’t possibly describe his relationship to Goal a romance. He treats her horribly and in the beginning it’s basically pure lust that drives him. Seeing how he slowly starts (!) to change is what made his character interesting.
And concerning Rufus’ father, I’d say that it’s just not true that this plotline gets dropped. Just look at the ending and the characters involved… the cliffhanger ending ties everything together.

Oh well. One last thing we agree on: This was merely an overture, the real adventure is just getting started. But personally, I’m very excited about that.

Bless you, Droggeljug!

reviewText: This is a puzzle game that can easily eat quite a bit of your time. It's pretty challenging but also lots of fun. That game offers you some reasonable liberty to explore around many places and find the items you need in any order. However, that might make you feel a bit lost or stuck at first, as you don't have idea of where to start. Quite a few times I got stuck because I didn't know what I should do or who I should talk with it. But it's just a matter of trying different combinations between your items and getting the clue of how certain things work in the area. Nonetheless, the game is pretty funny and worth the time spent. If you like challenging puzzles, hop on with Rufus in this hillarious adventure.

reviewText:
Review for the whole saga.

First of all, I don't really like point-and-click games,
but for some reasons... I loved Deponia saga.


Pros:

Awesome graphics
Awesome musics
Awesome voice acting
Nice story
FUNNY ! Dialogues\puzzles\descriptions\even trying to use the wrong item, will make you laugh.
The whole saga takes ~30h, it's never repetitive
Platypuses
Rufus
Great inventory system
Cons:
Last chapter (Goodbye Deponia) it's a bit buggy
I don't want to spoil so I'll just say that I'm REALLY REALLY REALLY disappointed with the ending...

reviewText:
BEFORE ANYTHING ELSE: IF YOU DOUBLE CLICK ON THE EXITS, YOU WILL MOVE TO THE NEXT SCREEN IMMEDIATELY, YOU DON'T HAVE TO WAIT FOR RUFUS TO WALK ALL THE WAY!

Hopefully this will get a chance to help people, I had the hardest time watching Rufus all the way across the center of the town.

I think this is another great piece of work from Daedalic Entertainment. Wonderful artwork and music as always. Difficult puzzles but nothing out of the unexpected if you have played any games from Daedalic.

At the beginning, the plot may seem a bit confusing since the setting does not get explained further on into the story. It's kind of hard to grasp the concept of Deponia and Elysium until later of the story. The first half of the game may seem a bit boring but the story is amazing if you could hold onto it until the very end.

What I do find interesting is that the protagonist is not your usual all-mighty or pure-hearted wonderful person. Rufus is an a-hole that does not have a job and nor does he appreciate his ex's help. Unfortunately the story does not tell into too much of Rufus past and explain why he may have became like that. Hopefully I will have time to play Chaos in Deponia very soon to find out more.

reviewText:
If you were stuck on a planet filled with nothing but junk and surrounded by idiots you’d want to escape right? Well if so then this is the game for you.

Help poor Rufus make his dream a reality and escape the junk ridden world of Deponia and make it all the way to the lofty heights of Elysium a floating city high above. And along the way meet a few new friends and enemies to boot. The story is pretty good and full of jokes and gags. I loved the writing and thought it was very well done. The characters are great too, each adding to the overall zaniness.

Deponia is a point a click game and as such the gameplay is pretty standard for the genre. The puzzles are not overly challenging but you may well be stumped a few times on the journey but each and every time you figure it out you feel pretty darn good. Clicking on everything that seems interesting to find all the needed objects and combining items together to overcome every obstacle can be very satisfying.

The game looks great; the art style is very unique and cartoony. Every set piece, character and item all fits nicely into the decaying world in which the game takes place. I loved exploring people’s homes and seeing what was used to build such wacky places. The game runs great, but as mentioned it’s a cartoon so there isn’t much the computer needs to generate. The game sounds great too; the music is fun and catchy. The sound effects are pretty comical and fit well in the title and every character is very well acted. I thought they all worked well together.

Although not ground breaking or particularly long it is a thoroughly enjoyable title from start to finish. I had great fun with it. At full price it’s a little steep but that being said if you like point and click or love the way the game looks or the comedy then go ahead and dive in. For the rest of us I’d wait for a sale, but it’s worth a look and will give you a few laughs.

Have fun ^_^

reviewText:
This is a fun adventure. You play Rufus who just want to get to Elysium and off Deponia, a planet full of dump and waste. The planet is thought to be uninhabited and ought to be destroyed by the Organon. But as it happens one of your tries to escape the planet had actually succeed in landing on an Organon cruiser. You and accidentally also the girl Goal from Elysium are dropped again on the planet’s surface. Your task is to a) save Goal, b) get Goal to Elysium to report that there is still life on Doponia and c) get yourself off the planet.

This can’t be hard, could it? Well it is. Since Rufus, your character, is a blighter, boaster, a loafer, which always exaggerated the opinion of himself. He can’t do nothing good and his tries to get off the planet as well as his inventions usually end up in total catastrophes. This is stuff for a lot of funny conversations and hilarious dialogues. The (german) voice acting is brilliant.

The planet, its people and also Rufus do entertain and are not without sympathy. The riddles are sometimes quite hard to solve and I did some by pure trial & error (which is no good).

Controlling the game is clever made, the scenarios are nice drawn and there is no room for a technical reproach.

8/10.

reviewText:
Great artstyle, great puzzles, great voice acting, great setting. Truely, a fantastic Point 'N' Click.
However, although the puzzles padded out the game, the plot didn't catch up. Not too much happens. Well...
NPCs give bits of lore, but the dialogue is unfortunately just repetetive banter with the protagonist. Although well written/translated, hearing the NPCs scold or embarrass the self-absorbed protagonist is just dull.
The mosaic minigame was bugged and impossible to complete. Luckily, there was a skip option. Which, to be honest, makes all of the (few) minigames fruitless.

If you've read all the above, it may seem like I am bashing the game. I'm not. Deponia, and its sequels, are a must-have for any patient gamer. And even Rufus manages to grow on you.

reviewText:
I'm not a fan of point-and-click adventures and i'm not quite good at them, honestly, but i liked the game's art and aesthetics and the fact that it was fully translated to my native language, so i bought it.
Playing the first chapter i was enjoing the game so much, then i found out by myself what people were talking about in their reviews: there's not a clear logic behind puzzles (why should i use a parrot with an emergency phone after i gave it coffee?) and i had to use several hints till i decided to give up.
Translations are good and voice acting too: anyhow i found it hard to follow Rufus' story where everyone is complaining about the main character even though he may be a complete a-hole; in addition to that, i wouldn't say humor is a merit at all, on the contrary i found dialogs quite frustrating.

Goodby Deponia.

EDIT: people are complaining that some achievements won't unlock and that's true. I have finished the game but its achievement didn't trigger.

reviewText:
Played through the opening thus far, and I had to go check out some other reviews of this and the later games.  I needed to know if things were going to get better.  The things that had attracted me to the purchase hadn't changed; beautiful art, great voicework, that old adventure touch.  But on playing the game, I found that, well, the protaganist is completely unlikable.

He's essentially a sociopath, and much of the humor is trying to play off of that.  From relentless abuse (from verbal to theft) of his Ex-Girlfriend to just blowing some people's houses up so you can take their place in a line, the Protaganist treats everything with egomanical contempt.  You're genuinely meant to find this behavior funny, but this game just doesn't work without something redeeming to latch onto.  At the end of the day, you're assisting a throughly unlikable person do generally unpleasent things, for 'humor'.  As to those reviews, I was hoping to find that he'd build towards that epifany moment and start to show some undercurrent of a likable person.  The counterpoint that makes putting up the rest funny, or at least bearable.

Unfortuantly, that doesn't ever seem to happen.  Rather, the game and particularly its sequals simply ramp up the acrimony.  Sale purchase so I can't complain too harshly, but this is one of the few games I've ever ran across that I genuinely regret purchasing.

reviewText:
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below)

Game Name: Deponia
Original Release: 2012
Genre Tags: Point & Click; Adventure; Charming; Funny
My Overall Grade: A-
Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 5-9 hours
Multiplayer Aspect: None
Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Casual gamers
REVIEWDeponia is a highly entertaining point-and-click misadventure with lovable characters, an interesting world, and wacky humor. If you like adventure games and goofy narratives, then look no further. It should be a pretty easy game to enjoy for most fans of the genre.

The crazy characters and zany game-world combined with the pleasing art style and soundscape make Deponia charming and atmospheric. This alluring ambiance is definitely the backbone of the game.  And as everything else falls into place, the overall presentation of the game just exudes an aura of “enjoyability” that is hard to defy.

Interestingly, the music and sound effects really play a much larger than usual role in the establishment of the ambiance. Relatedly, even the voice-acting in this game is not only well above the standard for the genre, but also objectively well performed. The end result shows how these elements can really help elevate the overall presentation of a game when they’re handled with care.

As far as gameplay goes: it is pretty standard for the genre. The puzzles are decently challenging and mostly fair; although some of the solutions don’t really make sense in terms of real-world thinking. You must remember to think in terms of the wacky logic of the game-world when solving puzzles. Sometimes it can be a little frustrating because it is hard to think like that. I suppose that if you get truly flabbergasted, you could always check a guide. Regardless of how you make it past the confusing parts, the rest of the presentation of the game is well worth experiencing.

So if you are a fan of point-and-click games, Deponia should be a good bet for you.  You definitely should beware of the outside-the-box (inside-the-game) logic, but in my opinion, it is one of the features of the game that makes it unique and worth playing.

Follow my curation page to see more of my recommendations!

reviewText:
This game shows the usual quality that is expected from Daedalic: Great production values for an adventure game, especially in terms of the animation. It’s also quite a novelty to play as an absolutely horrible person, and it’s interesting how that concept is integrated into the puzzles.

But still I think it was a missed opportunity, since the game suffers from many pacing issues and illogical puzzles. There are many parts where the objectives aren’t evident, when at the same time there are many screens and objects to interact. Also, there’s many puzzles that even after checking the walkthrough I’m still scratching my head, which is a big no no in this genre. Newcomers are advised to check The Whispered World instead.

reviewText: I thought I would like this game because it had good reviews and was compared to the Monkey Island series. Instead we have a game that's misogynist, transphobic and obtuse with a main character so unlikeable that I just gave up on the game. I didn't care about the fact that it had hard puzzles or ones that made no sense. I was expecting that, but Rufus is such a ♥♥♥♥ that I'm sad I even spent two bucks on this game. You can tell that they put a lot of work into it. I love the art in the game, I like the way that it looks and it sounds (voice acting aside), but... I just can't get past how juvenile and bigoted the humour is. Maybe that's the point. Maybe it's trying to be ironic in the way of South Park by being absolutely horrible for comedic effect and to draw attention to how stupid these tropes/stereotypes/etc sound.\n\nBut the problem with Deponia trying to do that? It's not funny. The jokes fall flat, the dialogue gets painful to listen to and I have never wished so much that there was a big cliff that I could just throw Rufus off over and over again.

reviewText: This game was a lot of fun.  I played this with my kids and we had a blast.  It was humourous (a little tacky at times) and reminded me of earlier games in this genre.  Most of the time it was clear what we needed to do to progress, but in some cases the puzzles are a bit obscure (this seemed to occur more in the sequels in this series).\n\nThe main character, Rufus is an arrogant resident of Deponia trying to leave for a better life.  Although it can be sometimes hard to truly cheer on this idiot, the quirkiness of the story and the game's puzzles keep you interested just to see what kind of trouble this guy is going to get into next.

reviewText: Great puzzles, great art, great voice acting, great sense of humor.  The only problem is that the first third of the game gets bogged down with a slow start to the story involving a giant meta-puzzle, that while well crafted isn't too interesting.  The main character evolves by the end of the game from someone you can't really stand to someone you really want to see succeed.  One of the better point and click adventures to come out in a while and absolutely should not by missed by fans of the genre.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Deponia, Chaos on Deponia, and Goodbye Deponia are point and click adventure games of old with a set of truly beautiful scenes and music.  The game and its series aims for classless humor and heavy amounts of schadenfreude.   If you're sensitive to any civil rights, human rights, animal rights, rights for the infirm, and rights of the wrongly convicted, you're likely to get offended at some point in this series.

You play as Rufus, a perpetual underdog that doesn't really seem to grasp that he's the underdog.  While he can be hard to relate to at times, especially in his moments of abscent minded cruelty, he has his good moments.

The female lead character is cheekedly called 'Goal,' which an obvious jab at other games where the female lead characters are often 'finish lines' rather than anything meaningful.  She stays true to her name throughout a fair bit of the first game, but becomes a living character towards the end of the first, and throughout the second and third games.

Deponia itself is a giant junkyard underneath a utopia-like society, not unlike worlds of Astroboy, and Battle Angel Alita, and Rufus is absolutely a man of his world.  The series is a long stream of connect the odds and ends to make things work" like many other games in the genre
date: and the theme of the game fits perfectly in the genre.\n\nUltimately
recommended: it's a fun ride.  The story and the humor
voteText: might leave a strange taste in your mouth
helpfulPercent: but its worth investing your time in."

reviewText: The music in this game is really well done, and the puzzles are generally funny and well thought out. My biggest issue with the entire series is the underlying racism and sexism that it presents throughout the three Deponia games. It is fairly disturbing encountering a puzzle where you need to sell the only black character in the series into slavery, because she could best mimic an organ grinder's monkey, for instance. More disturbing is that the designers saw this as the out of the box
recommended: the whole mechanic in the second game where the female protagonist's personality is split into its three core components of "sporty" "baby" and "stuck up" is emblematic of the kinds of criticisms for the endemic sexism that the gaming community has been receiving in the media of late."

reviewText:
As fan of adventure games, and one who has grown up on Monkey Island series and later games like Full throttle and Sanitarium, I was excited about playing this game... until 5 minutes in, when I got stuck first time. Ok, I google-it, found solution and continue on... for next 5 min, until I got stuck AGAIN! And after looking up on google for solution once more, I figured out system how this game works; enter area, play pixel hunting to find all clickable items so that you can collect them, then try out all items from inventory on all noncollectable items in that room, and if that doesn't work, then try to combine all items in your inventory one with another till you get new item. When you craft new item, try him out with everything in room, and then with everything in your inventory (because sometimes you have to combine more items to get something useful)... And if after all of that, you didn't do anything that will progress story further on, go to next area and repeat procedure. And you have to do all of that due to twisted and borderline insane logic behind all puzzles in this game, so there is very little things that will be logical at first (or ever).
So, does that sound like fun? For me it didn't... So I grabbed first walk-trough I found online, and finished game with it, and that makes me sad because characters (except main character), visuals, humor, animation and atmosphere are wonderful... Shame.

And I really can't say that I liked main character in this game (he is borderline sociopath); maybe they intended to do that, but It just make me dislike him in general, and If I don't like main character, I tend to like game less (this is personal preference, so take that that in consideration). And there are some questionable moral agendas in this game regarding females....

Overall, I don't recommend this game, due to insane puzzles that barely make any sense, and they reduce game to tedious clicking and trying out everything on everything until you make something new.
Score: 4/10
voteText: 14 of 29 people (48%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Looks pretty, seems fun enough, but a gratingly unlikable protagonist sucks any possible enjoyment out of this game.

reviewText:
I'll fully admit I bought this for the art style. In that regard, Deponia is exactly what it advertises. The chunky, eccentric designs of characters and backgrounds really brings this game to life.

And that's where the praise ends.

The big issue here is the writing, and it commits what is, to me, the greatest sin. It's trying to be funny. The jokes come at you on a regular basis. But I did not laugh once in my entire playthrough. Perhaps it's because of the mean nature of much of the humor, or it's a style that just doesn't carry over in translation, but most of the time the characters just seemed unlikable and mean-spirited.

My thought is that if you don't get laughs, stop it. Just stop it. Tell a story, be earnest in your delivery, drop all the affected attempts at hilarity. Maybe then they could have spent more time on the puzzles, which range from arbitrary to insulting.

There's a puzzle where you literally have to make an association between the house a person lives in and what their hat is, because three people all have headgear that looks like their occupation. It's that sort of backwards engineered idiot puzzle that makes people give up on adventure games. It has to be logical, sensible but not obvious, or the player will just give up.

This is the sort of series I'd rather view through one of those Let's Play" Youtube series
date: but preferrably with the sound off."

reviewText:
Insane Adventure Game Logic: now with weird European humor!The characters and setting are interesting enough that I'll probably watch a playthrough video, but having to check a walkthrough every few minutes to figure out what insane thing you have to do gets old FAST.

For example, before you're allowed to leave the first area, Rufus has to collect four items to pack into his suitcase. Bringing a clean pair of socks seems easy - I found a blue and a yellow sock, but Rufus wanted a matching pair. Okay... Rufus says they're dirty, so let's try washing them in boiling water, which results in the two socks coming out as ONE green sock. I had to check a walkthrough to find out that there's another green sock completely hidden under Rufus' pillow... did I mention that the game is set on a garbage planet, but the few items that you can actually interact with aren't highlighted? (edit: apparently there's a button you can press to highlight items you can interact with... quality UI design!)

One of the other four items you need to pack is Rufus' toothbrush, which comes alive and runs and hides because of how filthy Rufus' teeth have been on the rare times he's brushed them. Okay, I can live with the idea of a sentient toothbrush, heck as a kid I even used to watch a cartoon with that exact premise. So how would you think that an adventure game would have you lure out an abused toothbrush? Maybe by tempting it with nice teeth to brush, such as by somehow convincing another character (with superior dental hygiene) to smile near the toothbrush? Nope, you catch it with a mousetrap... with a pea for bait. What?! And you find that mousetrap in a closet" which just looks like part of the wall (did I mention how visually messy the garbage planet setting is?). The game implies that you need something to pry the closet door open
date: and the required tool turns out to be a TOILET PLUNGER.\n\nI think that was when I gave up on the game."

reviewText:
My oh my... I mean, this game does have neat visuals. And sometimes it is funny. The puzzles are moderate in obscurity and difficulty.

On the other hand the main character (Rufus) is the most obnoxious, arrogant, sexist and stubborn main character I have ever seen. It was very hard playing as him and hear him make simple, often unfunny and unnecessary comments. And the way he talks about women... He despises the first one even though she (god knows why) literally provides the roof above his head, and the other one he treats as if she were his property. Besides that, the game is riddled with dirty humour and a story that really makes no sense and gives no explanation.

I would have loved it if as the game progressed, Rufus evolved and became humbler and reasonable. But no. And thus, I would not recommend, unless you really only care about the puzzles or do not care about depth of character.

reviewText:
I've seen what this game has to offer, though not on Steam. Trust me: Deponia is the Adam Sandler of adventure games. Sometimes, it creeps up to being the Will Farrell of adventure games. More often, it's somewhere in the middle, like Ben Stiller. At no point is it really all that fun for any length of time.

Graphics aren't everything, but they're everything to Deponia.  Once you get past the screenshots, there are no redeeming qualities to the game. Generally, Deponia involves a clunky, unattractive interface, stupid amounts of not-just-difficult-but-illogical puzzles, a plot that creeps forward like molasses in January, an unattractive protragonist and an unfunny script.

Go play a fun adventure game, like Broken Age, or Full Throttle, or the Monkey Island games. Stay away from Deponia. At best, buy it and watch a Let's Play.

PS: The major flaw in this game is that it has little to no replay value.

reviewText:
Deponia is a traditional point–and-click (P&C) adventure game which revolves around the protagonist trying to escape from Deponia and ends up saving a mysterious princess. Boasting a charming setting supported by beautifully drawn backgrounds, solid voice acting  and an interesting soundtrack, at its core it is plagued by one of the most insufferable casts and puzzles seen in an adventure game in years.

If the aim of the game was to represent the most insufferable protagonist, something which is fundamentally a backbone of the genre, then it passed with flying colours. Rufus, the protagonist, is quintessentially the pretentious and brainless (at times) jerk every individual should respectfully hate and gives little reason for any sympathy throughout most of the story, even when his act of saving the princess is noble to an extent. Not only is the protagonist ultimately unlikeable, but almost every single support character faces the same setback: being painfully unmemorable, unfunny or annoying.

The humour in Deponia is by and large hit-and-miss. There are a few genuine moments which spark a giggle such as a robot’s guilty obsession with popping bubble-wraps or a transvestite’s fake womanly voice (the best it can get), but these are overshadowed by the blatant misogynistic remarks and uninspiring jokes by poorly written characters.

The puzzles are not great either. They start off fairly easy but eventually end up suffering from a typical syndrome in this genre -- illogicality. Because of this a guide must be acquired, otherwise too much time will be frustratingly spent figuring out what to do next, and there are a few moments where you will ask yourself how were you supposed to know that or why that particular action was required. The game does not give too many hints when it comes to solving its relatively tiresome puzzles.

All of the things mentioned above slowly turn a potentially decent storyline at best into a dreary one. Even now, personally I am not completely sold on the whole damsel in distress approach the story takes when Rufus meets the princess, who spends mostly the entire game unconscious from a fall caused by no one else but Rufus earlier in the game. Regardless, there is also a sense of not much engagement in the story either, all thanks to poor writing. After a few hours sank into the game, everything starts to be a big fat chore.

From a technical standpoint, it is shocking to realise that after almost two years since launch a particular game-breaking glitch in a puzzle, which was also encountered by others (albeit not all), is still present in the game. This glitch stops a particular cutscene to play, preventing any possibility of continuing the game just when you were so close to the end. After some research, a way to overcome this unforgiveable misfortunate is to get access of a save file from someone else who owns the game and got passed this point. At the time of writing this review, I still do not know how the game actually ends. Moreover, reported by others as well is the awful framerate even for high-end computers which can inexplicably drop to as low as 10FPS even at the lowest settings. Deponia is a game which should not require a lot of resources to run smoothly considering it looks like a 2D game done in Flash, and this implies poor coding and optimization.  Lastly, the animations can be a bit clunky at times but passable.

Conclusively, Deponia is kind of a mess, much like its planet. Poor writing, unlikeable characters, illogical puzzles and unfixed glitches simply make it a chore or potentially unplayable and degrade anything interesting the story has to offer.  Its visual charm might be its only selling point for anyone curious about Deponia (mainly the reason I got it), but its flaws in almost everything that is supposed to make a top-notch adventure P&C sadly suck out any enjoyment Deponia could offer to an avid, yet old-school, adventure fan like myself. I cannot recommend this game to any adventure fanatic expecting an overall quality on par to Monkey Island, Gabriel Knight, Broken Sword and other classics. Instead, Deponia should also take an example from a recent modern game like The Book Of Unwritten Tales.

Lastly, if you can actually ignore all its flaws, then it is passable at best. But I would be in awe by how you could ignore such obvious flaws.

reviewText:

reviewText:
This is a fantastic point-n-click adventure game. If you've played any of the old LucasArts or Sierra adventure games from the 90's, you'll feel right at home with Deponia. It's art style and sense of humor is reminiscient of Monkey Island or Day of the Tentacle, and its puzzles are definitely challenging without being outlandishly obscure. It's a perfect balance of logic and wackiness.

The story and characters are also well done, though it took a little bit for the main character, Rufus, to grow on me (he's obnoxious and grating at first). Since this is part 1 of a trilogy, the ending will leave you hanging and wanting more. However, don't let that fool you into thinking it cuts short. I finished this in 12 hours, which is unheard of for point-n-click games in this day and age.

If you loved the adventure games in the 90's from LucasArts or Sierra, this is definitely worth your time and money, and I can't wait to play the sequels.

reviewText:
When this game showed up on my radar, it had *sooo* much potential to be the next Monkey Island. While it doesn't completely fall short, it does enough wrong to not get my vote.

Pros:
-Art style is really polished.
-Music (especially intro) is surprisingly good.
-Length is about what point-and-click adventures should be.
-The idea of calling a trilogy from the begining is a great idea.

Cons:
-I need my point-and-click adventures to be more or less logic driven. What I mean is that the items I try to use to solve the problem should make some sort of sense (even if it is quite tangential). This game suffers very badly from matching up logic to solve problems. Alot of the time it ends up being random clicking that gets you through. This is not very satisfying.
-There is some sort of language barrier as some of the jokes are questionable lol. I find it funny but I would be willing to bet that the humor/script was written for another culture (I am located in North America).

I also played the second game in the trilogy, and will not be visiting the third. Not a complete waste of time, but there are better games out there (plus I payed the full 20$ asking price).

reviewText:
I like Point & Click Adventures. I love how they tell their stories and create their worlds. But I must make an admission about me and this genre.

I cheat profusely at Adventure games...

To me its the destination thats more crucial to Adventure games than the journey. It takes away from the overall experience if I have to try every item on my inventory on everything in the environment. so apologies to those who object me to using walkthroughs. Moving on....

Deponia's story is an interesting one. Rufus, a do nothing, egotistical and self-involved young man who desperately wants to leave his stinking junkyard homeworld Deponia for the utopian floating city of Elysium. His latest hair brained plan to escape almost succeeded had he gets involved in an incident and rescues a mysterious girl, knocking her into a coma in the process. Its a funny and light hearted story with a touching cast that still delivers some swift plot twists and one liners (all voiced as well). All of which is pleasingly punctuated by the games detailed, cartoon art style that takes you in (with some help from the music....).

Gameplay is as it has always been for Point & Clicks; you study the scene, collect everything and solve esoteric puzzles that put the Gordian Knot to shame. I'm not gonna delve too much into it since I use walkthroughs. But I will say its a fair bit better controls than other adventure games I've played.

Deponia is a fun game, but like all Point & Click adventures its not for everyone. More for the inquisitive type in it for the story than the action. I'm already ready too dive into the sequel.

As well as finish The Secret of Monkey Island...

reviewText: Really adorable character designs, interesting storyline peppered with silly one-liners... I really wanted to like this game, I wanted to be so into it that I bought the sequels. The puzzles were appropriate at progressing the plot, not too easy nor complex... then the emergency phone in the centre of town didn't have a click option so I had to reload saves then replay from the start to find it had ironed out. Then I was condemned to a replaying cutscene before reaching the station that made my character return to the control room like I had completed a puzzle incorrectly when I hadn't. Over and over I had to try to push past it. I don't mind a few bugs but then I uninstalled when I reached the whale. Why? Because the puzzle seemed forced like someone just wanted to extend the gameplay and I realised, so close to the end, the game had lost it's spark. Inventive and sweet to look at, I want to recommend it but cannot as it hooked me in and just completely dulled me out.

reviewText:
I like Point & Click Adventures. I love how they tell their stories and create their worlds. But I must make an admission about me and this genre.

I cheat profusely at Adventure games...

To me its the destination thats more crucial to Adventure games than the journey. It takes away from the overall experience if I have to try every item on my inventory on everything in the environment. so apologies to those who object me to using walkthroughs. Moving on....

Deponia's story is an interesting one. Rufus, a do nothing, egotistical and self-involved young man who desperately wants to leave his stinking junkyard homeworld Deponia for the utopian floating city of Elysium. His latest hair brained plan to escape almost succeeded had he gets involved in an incident and rescues a mysterious girl, knocking her into a coma in the process. Its a funny and light hearted story with a touching cast that still delivers some swift plot twists and one liners (all voiced as well). All of which is pleasingly punctuated by the games detailed, cartoon art style that takes you in (with some help from the music....).

Gameplay is as it has always been for Point & Clicks; you study the scene, collect everything and solve esoteric puzzles that put the Gordian Knot to shame. I'm not gonna delve too much into it since I use walkthroughs. But I will say its a fair bit better controls than other adventure games I've played.

Deponia is a fun game, but like all Point & Click adventures its not for everyone. More for the inquisitive type in it for the story than the action. I'm already ready too dive into the sequel.

As well as finish The Secret of Monkey Island...

reviewText: The puzzles are good, aside from a few that seem too obscure even for an adventure game, the art is amazing and the plot is solid. However, the characters and dialogue ruin the whole experience from me, and in a game where you have to talk to everyone to get clues and hints, it seems like a huge failing/\nThe protagonist is terribly unlikable, and though that is the point of his character, it's not pulled off well. He's grating and annoying the entire time, rather than any kind of funny or charming. Most of the side characters are average-to-annoying, though it can't go unnoticed that the only 3 women that actually appear are 'naggy ex', 'man-in-a-dress joke' and Goal, who could basically be replaced with an attractive suitcase at any given time.\nSo basically, if you're just in it for the puzzles, great. If you want something deepers, eh, try something else.

reviewText:
Decent Point N Click game thats a bit of a messy ride due to bad optimisation and design choices & errors. It has some flaws thats common in this genre though with stupid design choices that forces you to listen over some of the dialogue you just heard over and over if you dont do the right thing both in some conversations and puzzles. for example the 2-3 harder puzzles in the game would have environments where there would be some really annoying looping sounds which makes it really frustrating to focus on the puzzle. The games humour is a bit hit & miss but overall on the positive side.

Warning: This game on the other hand atleast the Steam version on the other hand is extremely bugged though atleast on Windows 7. There was tons of errors where the mouse wouldnt register actions at hotspots, also some places easpecially in the 2nd half and onwards in the game there are looping sound bugs which is especially frustrating when trying to solve a puzzle i had to skip one of em because i didnt find a fix for the sound. Some of the later parts a restart or a reloading of a save file would fix the sound loop at times or leaving a area and go back. Since the game originates from a german company theres also some bugs where the subtitles will be shown in german and i even got spanish voices at 1 point(!).

I wont recommend buying the Steam version if you really want this game, the GOG.com version is far better compatible and doesnt seem to have as many bugs overall.

Rating: 6/10

reviewText: As someone who grew up with point and click games, (specifically the ones from Humongus Games) this game gave me huge flashbacks to my childhood playing games like Putt Putt or Freddie Fish, except with more mature language. The main character has a load of personality, and the story has this Elysium" feel to it
date: but with a lot more charisma than that movie ever could have accomplished. My only minor complaint with the game is I wish the voices and sounds weren't so compressed. The game's visuals are so gorgeous
recommended: that hearing the grainy voices and midi type sound effects really throws me off into this sort of uncanny valley effect.\n\nBut yeah
hoursPlayed: it's good. Go check it out."

reviewText:
It is a nice game with decent graphics and funny story, and I have even played and finished it at my friends computer when it was originally released, but sadly there there are some (randomly appearing) blocking bugs which makes the game unfinishable (from time to time). And as I rememeber, some of these bugs were there even when the game was originaly released, which was more than year ago. And gues what - they are still there (and if somebody is interested what is the problem is /this time/: there is no way to leave radio operator tower when he is overwhelmed by all the incomming comunications).

So if you are willing to try to avoid these bugs (and possibly (re)play the game from the beginning for several times during the process), then go ahead and buy it, it is a GREAT funny game. You may even be so lucky that you will not encounter any of the bugs :)

For everyone else - stay clear of it, you will get frustrated from triing to avoid these bugs...
voteText: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Long, uninteresting, unintelligent dialogs, confusing and illogical puzzles, and a boring set of characters makes me never want to finish this game.

Spoiler alert! The solution to one of the puzzles is to put two socks in a pot of boiling water. You use a fork to get them out, the fork disappears and you are left with only one sock. What!? I just put two socks in the pot and one of them disappears. I thought there was a bug in the game so I restarted and replayed everything up to the boiling water puzzle. Looking at the walkthrough revealed that there is a third sock under the pillow in the bed. Sigh!

Oh, and the tutorial is the longest, most annoying, over explained, not funny at all tutorial for a game that doesn't need a tutorial.

Deponia tries very hard to be Monkey Island. Even the voice of the protagonist sounds like Guybrush. Compared to Monkey Island, Deponia does not have the same finesse. You will never laugh out loud, or be surprised by the puzzles or enjoy the dialogue. The characters you meet feel very one dimensional and unintelligent. They lack the depth the characters of Monkey Island have. In my eyes, this game doesn't add anything new to the adventure genre, and it certainly isn't Monkey Island.

reviewText:
An interesting little game that is let down by serious performance issues.

While the art style and story were interesting enough to keep me playing, more than once I hit game-stopping bugs that forced me to kill the game from the task manager. The worst one halted progress during the final moments of the game, and when the game re-booted and allowed me to proceed all audio was cut out, leaving the closing scenes of the game to play out in silence.

All of that could have been forgiven if the game wasn't so incredibly sluggish. When changing between areas it takes a few more seconds for anything to be able to intractable. So skipping around the town goes from being quick and painless to forehead vs. keyboard frustrating.

If they can fix the loading and the bugs it'd be worth a look at, but in its current state your time would be better spent elsewhere.

reviewText:
Pros:
+Light-hearted game that makes lots of attempts at humor (some of them successful), especially in the dialog
+Interesting setting and a likable main character

Cons:
-Pacing of the story is very poor. The story moves forward in a very jerky way with 30 second cutscenes of story followed by long, tedious bouts of point-and-click puzzle solving full of very contrived quests which are barely related to the story. (For example: To advance the story by one small increment, you've got to collect these six things. Oh, and each one will have some asinine obstacle blocking your ability to get it.) By the end of each of these game segments I was positively starved for some kind of progress in the story and on the verge of quitting. The story is interesting, but it moves at a snail's pace. It's super-annoying to play for an hour without getting so much as a crumb of story progress. This made the game feel long and dull to me.
-I found several of the puzzles to be confusing rather than challenging. In a couple of cases I got the solution through random trial and error before actually understanding what the puzzle was I was supposed to be solving.
-The story is completely unresolved, and all you get in the end is a to be continued" ending."

reviewText:
OK.... this is a NO review...
I always try to be supportive of even the crappiest game, but this.... is... a bit too much crap for my taste.

Before reading, please, if you are a huge fan of Daedalic games, you might find this review offensive.
Actually, you WILL find this offensive.

Do not read.

I warned you.

First of all, the MC.
GAWD the only reason I ended this game was because I was too anal not to finish. I had lots and LOTS of AFK moments to cool down JUST BECAUSE of the MC. I'd rather play a total villain than this sad excuse for an anti-hero.
I even turned off the audio because I hated listening to his dialogues, and yes, I also skipped through all.

Next, the NPCs.
Seriously, they are just as bad... except for 2 who were ridiculously harassed by the MC. I actually like these 2 and wonder, if the character designers are actually capable of creating these 2 great characters, then why is the MC such a crap??????
You have anti-heroes, and you have jerks. I don't see any of the first in this game.

Plot was OK. The world setting reminded me of the Japanese manga GUNM : Battle Angel Alita.

Graphics are good. A good reminiscence of Monkey Island and Gabriel Knight (the 2D animation versions).

Soundtrack.... no idea. I was so irritated by the MC's dialogue etc then I turned off the audio completely except when I needed it to solve puzzles. Even then I didn't register it into mind.

Puzzle.
The puzzles are FRUSTRATING and does not make sense. Yes, it's a fantasy world which isn't logical in the first place, but  unfortunately for puzzles, you do need logic. Fantasy world or not.
The order does not make sense. I know what to do, and IMO it doesn't effect the game whatsoever if we mix up the orders anyway. But nooooooo..... we miss a step, we can't move on.

I purchased a LOT of Daedalic games in a shopping binge because I was desperate for a good point-click game.
Played 3, finished 2, and not even thinking about finishing the 3rd despite my anal-ness.
Not even thinking about starting the other ones, and will re-fund if possible.
If re-fund not possible, I might play the remaining games just to humor the money I spent, which is NOT happening anytime soon.

If you're an avid collector of point-click games no matter what review, then go ahead and give this a try, though I do recommend... HIGHLY recommend that you purchase this only on a big sale.

If you're looking for a good gaming time, move along. This is one game you can totally live without.

reviewText:
Daedalic Entertainment, once called “Lucasarts from Germany“ by the GameStar magazine, invites the players into a fantastic comedy adventure that revolves around a crazy love story of Rufus and Goal.

In Deponia, the world has degenerated into a vast garbage dump, in which the crotchety Rufus ekes out his sorry existence. He is part of the lowest social class, doomed to live his life in literal mountains of trash. He hopes for an opportunity to get into the world of the rich, who live in a floating city high above the clouds. Fate seems to smile on the snotty good-for-nothing when one day the attractive lady named Goal from the higher sector plummets into one of the trash heaps. Rufus decides to help the young woman out by taking her back to her husband. When he notices that Goal's husband is a dead ringer for himself, he hatches a diabolical scheme to gain access to the upper world. However, things don't work out quite as planned, since he has feelings for the beauty which limits his usual unscrupulousness.

Help Rufus, the poor boy from the junkyard, to win over the girl from heaven. Only with this rich girl from his dreams he might be able to escape Deponia and, unexpectedly, to save the planet.

reviewText:
Deponia is the 1st part of Rufus's story. A guy from Deponia planet (a.k.a. a junkyard) that is trying to leave his miserable life in Deponia in order to travel up to the luxurius Elysium. An excellent point and click game with cartoonish graphics and amazing humor. When playing this game you must only got one thing in your mind. Try any combination between items and/or npcs. Any idea, no matter how crazy looks like, might work. With funny result almost 100% of the time.

Pros:
+ Graphics
+ Story
+ Humor
+ Puzzles
+ Runs flawless in Win 8.1
+ Many language, subtitle and resolution options

Cons
- Some minigames would need a hint or 2 but you can still skip them
- The end...? Made me wanna play more.
- The walking speed is low but you can still teleport from one place to other by double clicking.

I consider Deponia as a little diamond which everyone should have in his gaming collection.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
From the makers of ''The Dark Eye: Chains of Satinav''. ''Deponia'' is a game developed and pubished by Daedalic Entertainment.

Preface!
Due to this game being ''story driven'', I am not going to go into mush detail or spoil anything major of the Story.

The story centers around Rufus: a young, sarcastic, bold, lying, selfish man who wants to leave the junk town of Kovaq - a town Rufus has known for so long - and look for his, not-so known, father. Rufus believes his father abandoned him for the floating city of Elysium when Rufus was very young.

And so, Rufus makes it his ultimate destiny to go to Elysium; to prove his own father that Rufus can go to Elysium.

During Rufus Journey, he ends up meeting people and they end up helping him on his travel.

The tone of the story is comedy mixed with seriousness. About 95% of the game is comedy while the small 5% is seriousness. I can't say in which part the game gets serious.

The ending of the game, in a way, touched my heart. I can't say  in detail of what happened in the ending, but it got to do with all Rufus had done during his Jouney.


I like Deponias' animation. The animation is hand drawn. The animation suits well with the comedic tone of the game.


Deponia is a hard point-and-click game and is a lot more harder than ''The Dark Eye: Chains of Satinav''.
Items do not ''highlight'' when you hover over them with something else.

There is no quest log... so... you are probably going to wander aimlessly around in the game and be like ''uhmm... what am I suppose do again?''.

I recommend this game to people who wants a challengine Point-and-click game.
Deponia gets an 8/10.

reviewText: Whimsical point and click adventure. It's a colorful little world and a nice addition to a faded genre, but it displays some telltale signs of why the genre has faded. You'll hit at least a handful of moments where the game becomes less about figuring out clever little puzzles and more about trying every different thing on every other thing until something works. Also, the voice acting is unfortunately pretty terrible. so much so, that you might even consider muting it so you don't have to hear the same lines repeated over and over again as you progress through dialogue trees. The game took me about 10 hours to complete, but I was ready for it to be over after about 6.\n\nThis is first in a trilogy. If you like point-and-click, it will entertain. But I'd recommend trying this one out before pulling the trigger on the complete Deponia series.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: Point and click adventure game like the classics! The story is funny and interesting and the main character is amusingly inept and egotistical. Completely surprised to find such a high quality adventure game like this out there. I will definitely play the sequels!
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: The whole Deponia series comprises some of my favourite point-and-click adventure games. They're fun, hilarious, and for the most part the puzzle solutions made sense but were still challenging. The story itself is fantastic, and full of laughs. The gameplay I never found tedious or boring, and there are no tiny hotspots that you just can't quite click that make some other point-and-click games so frustrating. The voice acting, music, and especially the art are all very well done. I highly recommend all the games in this series, but this first is my favourite of the three, and if you're only ever going to play one Daedalic Entertainment game, this should be it!

reviewText: This game has by far one of the best stories I've ever seen in a game. Not only is it comical and puzzling at the same time, but Rufus is so relatable (To me anyway). With all of his escapades, and disasters associated with him the community doesn't take a liking to him... well, nobody really takes a liking to him. But! He loves himself and I do think that is actually a really good and strong message, even though that it is pretty vague and probably not intentional by any means. It teaches people that it doesn't matter what other people think of you, if you believe in yourself and put all the nessicary work in you can accomplish anything. 10/10

reviewText:
Pros:

- Great storytelling and humourous writing around an unsual love story.
- Great artwork and comic visuals. The concepts of Deponia makes it rather unique in visual styles.
- Odd and funny puzzles abound, but nothing ridiculous - they do make sense in a way.

Cons:

- The story's pacing is actually somewhat slow. Essentially you move from one area to another, solve a set of puzzles, then move on.
- Some subtitle problems - not matching what was actually said.
- A few sound effect problems - they came slower than the actual animation.

reviewText:
If I could marry a game developer it would be Daedalic.
Their love for the small things is without comparison.
But not only the setting is overwhelming beautiful (just by the way it's drawn). The story mixes everything they've done right in edna, the whispered world and the night of the rabbit into a perfect game and a fantastic start into a wonderful journey to deponia.
There's no better way to start a trilogy.

Lovelines: 	  9/10 (do you feel the developer's love for the game)
Creativity: 	  8/10 (is it something overwhelmingly creative)
Thrill: 		  9/10 (do you want to know how it continues)
Music:		10/10 (pays the music tribute to the game or is it just boring?)
Story:		10/10 (Does it have a story and is it great?)
Bugfree:		10/10 (Does it have any bugs? is it an enjoyable playthrough?)

Total:		9.3/10

To put it in a nutshell:
A great Adventure for rainy days ( and sunny days) and the whole trilogy is perfect for a great weekend of bingegaming.
Have a nice play

reviewText:
play hotheaded rufus, as he follows his goals to get goal's approval.

I played this point and click game before any of the Telltale games. This is the game that got me into point and click games. The game starts off really quickly, and things are explained/taught to the audience really quickly. I liked the 2D animation of this game, as well as the horizontal AND vertical movement that existed.

The humor in this game was really funny, and well done, and the cinematics were great. I found the length of this game to be just right, and the puzzles hard, but not hard enough that I had to resort to a guide.

The only downfall to this game is the price. I have been waiting and eagerly watching the other 2 Deponia games to go on sale so I can continue my story. Buy at sale price only, $20 for a point and click (that's not telltale) is ridiculous.

reviewText: I highly recommend this if you're a fan of classic Lucasarts point and click games.  The game really shines with its beautiful enviornments, memorable characters(especially the main character, Rufus), entertaining story, and overall good sense of humor.  However, just like a lot of other point and click adventures it suffers from a lack of conveyance. If you're not sure about it try the demo, it gives you a good sense of what the game and it's puzzles are like.

reviewText:
This series.

What can I say.

This ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ series. Has. EVERYTHING that makes a point-and-click adventure game work. Fantastic puzzles, insane and colorful characters, a story that simulateously makes you laugh and cry with Rufus at the same time.

Speaking of our egotistical main character, never before have I wanted to give a fictional game character a slap and a hug at the same time. The dude is unbelieveably self-centered, but at the same time he tried his best to keep his shenanigans from harming people. He wants to leave Deponia, but he can't just let people call Deponians trash. The planet? Yeah it's trash, but the people mean well and are just trying to get by, and are in no way trash.

This character. This world.

THIS SERIES. IS. AMAZING.
10/10
GET ALL THREE GAMES IT'S AMAZING.

reviewText:
A beautiful looking game with an ugly personality.

While this game looks amazing it is blatantly misogynistic, full of bugs and rarely funny. Many of the puzzles don't make sense and the main character is just annoying. Why do I want to play as this jerk?

The game is visually polished with high production values, but non of that matters once you start reading the sexist and misogynistic dialogue.

I played the whole game through to the end and it only gets worse as the game progresses, more bugs, more crashes and more misogyny.

I love adventure games, but I hate this one.

reviewText:
Deponia is a classic point-and-click adventure game in the style of the classic LucasArts adventure games of time long past.  It's a futuristic-type tale that takes place on, you guessed it, Deponia, a toxic world of trash that the upper crust left behind a long time ago to live on the floating city of Elysium.  Rufus, the protagonist, has had enough of living on Deponia, and is actively trying to reach Elysium by any means necessary.  There have already been a few failed attempts by the time the game starts, but this new one is entirely different.

THE GOOD:
Beautiful hand-drawn animation.  Especially beautiful in the cutscenes where they bring in some CG to really bring it to life.
Faithful, true to its roots adventure game
Wonderful voice acting
Is genuinely funny most of the way through.  It can be hit-and-miss, but it's more hits than misses
THE BAD:
A lot of little translation issues that, I think, could just have been solved by one good editing pass from a native speaker
Mostly unlikeable characters, with a few exceptions.  They're the exception and not the rule, though
Weird attitudes toward women in general
It's a faithful adventure game throwback.  Serious case of adventure game logic.
TL;DR If you like a good, classic adventure game and don't mind a little bit of jank, it's a good example of one and is decently funny to boot.  If a lot of minor issues with language, character, and writing will get in the way of you enjoying this game, I can't really recommend it that much.  Personally, I would think that I would be in the second camp, and I spend a lot of time kind of tearing at it for its myriad faults, but I'm ultimately not sorry I played this game.  If you can pick it up for like $5, I'd say go for it.  It's really pretty.

If you want to read more of my thoughts on it, I'll go into some more detail.

The game was developed by Daedalic Entertainment, based out of Germany, and it is immediately obvious that this game wasn't originally written in English.  The lyrics of the singing interludes by the chorus-type character have been cruelly shoved into some kind of rough rhyming scheme, one that I am sure plays a lot better in German.  The subtitles of the translation are also littered with grammatical errors (at one point the subtitles read motive" where the spoken text correctly reads the line as "motif")
date: which is a real shame to see because I don't think that hiring a decent editor - one that has a firm grasp of the English language - would be that difficult.  Some of the lines don't play exactly correctly
hoursPlayed: as the voice actors place the wrong emphasis on the wrong word at points.  These are lines which could be read differently in context and it would be a producer or director's job to ensure that they read correctly according to the situation.  In short
voteText: the dialogue is a little janky.  Not enough to ruin the experience
helpfulPercent: but it's there
votesHelpful: and if you're as annoying about grammar as I am then it'll bother you too.\n\nWhich isn't to say that the VO in the game is bad.  They actually get some decent actors
votesTotal: including Alix Wilton Regan of Mass Effect 3
votesFunny: and more recently Dragon Age: Inquisition fame
commentsCount: and they turn out a great performance.  With what they're given.\n\nThere isn't a lot to like about the main characters in Deponia.  Rufus
column16: your protagonist
column17: is kind of a dirtbag.  He gleefully smashes his way through everything in sight trying to reach his goal (and his Goal; the Elysian girl he accidentally knocks out of the sky at the beginning of the game is literally named Goal this game is not subtle at all) and he just runs roughshod over everyone while proclaiming how brilliant and compassionate he is.  I'll admit
column18: some of his lines are genuinely funny
column19: but over the course of the game I just felt like I was getting hit over the head by how much of a real jerk this guy was.  Even when you
column20: the player

column22: the person you're talking to basically disregards it and you get railroaded into something awful happening.  And I can understand why it's written that way
column23: because Rufus has some big ol' glaring flaws that he needs to work through for redemption

In one scene the men of the town all bid to be the one to take the beautiful girl home and "care for her."  Goal herself spends most of the game passed out and is only an object that Rufus has to carry from point A to point B and call his girlfriend without even talking to her.    I don't like the story as much as I could have
column26: for sure.\n\nDeponia is a classically styled adventure game.  Which means you have a gigantic inventory

column29: and then use every item on every interactable object to try and make the game go.  In an effort to make the game challenging it also has a bad case of adventure game logic

reviewText:
HUZZAH WITH BOOZE AND SO FORTH!

On it's own it's a pretty damn good adventure game, as a trilogy it's a game to ♥♥♥♥ing remember. Sure, not every joke hits it's mark (three of which in particular in Goodbye Deponia are seriously in bad taste), but any missteps aside it still reaches it's Goal.

Concering all three games:
I don't think it would be fair to just say it has good writing and leave it at that. It's incredibly unqiue in what it does and how it aims to achieve it. The main character and many of the puzzles, and the plot that unfolds as a result of the puzzles is an interesting deconstruction of the genre. The story is often cheesy at times, but by the end it will blindslide you with the message it's trying to send. That message is powerful, and isn't one you see every day. It's ♥♥♥♥ing brilliant.

reviewText:
It's alright. Deponia is a point-and-click adventure with at least some of the obtuse and convoluted puzzle solving that genre entails. I liked the story as it was certainly interesting, but the character you control is entirely without depth or real personality. Technically speaking, it's an unoptomized mess that runs very poorly and is riddled with bugs.

Thankfully, the game allows skipping puzzles because there exists a bug that not only makes one of the puzzles incoherent and unsolvable through normal means, but, even given a working solution, it will not allow progress beyond the puzzle.

It's short, but fun. Get it when it's cheap.

reviewText:
What drew me to this game was its amazing art style. In fact, many of the scenes from the game have become my rotating Desktop Wallpapers. This game is a joy to play, with plently of interesting chaarcters to meet. Rufus, though he is a assholish neanderthal, he still kept endearing himself, especiall his little tantrum near the end of the game.

The puzzles are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t though. I am no ashamed that I looked at a guide, because ♥♥♥♥ the game without it. Still I figured out many of them out by myself, so with patince you can solve them.

ANyway heartil reccomend. If you use a guide, it can be a little on the short side, butstill good. Also check out Chaos on Deponia, the sequel, and Goodbye Deponia, the final game.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: Fun game, is what can be said. The world is an interesting mix of Douglas Adams and Terry Pratchett styles, and the story, maybe not the most unique ever, is capturing and fun. The graphics are reminiscent of The Curse of Monkey Island. You know, those hand painted backgrounds! The main character, Rufus, is a fun guy but can be seen at times as obnoxious and unlikable, but he does make up for it in the end. The ending, which I do not wish to spoil, was incredible and not predictable. Some of the jokes feel forced at times and the puzzles may seem tedious (but there's a skip button for those more frustrated gamers). Get it, and play it. It's well worth it, and experience the wonder that is Deponia!

reviewText:
A beautiful looking game with an ugly personality.

While this game looks amazing it is blatantly misogynistic, full of bugs and rarely funny. Many of the puzzles don't make sense and the main character is just annoying. Why do I want to play as this jerk?

The game is visually polished with high production values, but non of that matters once you start reading the sexist and misogynistic dialogue.

I played the whole game through to the end and it only gets worse as the game progresses, more bugs, more crashes and more misogyny.

I love adventure games, but I hate this one.

reviewText:
Pros:

- Great storytelling and humourous writing around an unsual love story.
- Great artwork and comic visuals. The concepts of Deponia makes it rather unique in visual styles.
- Odd and funny puzzles abound, but nothing ridiculous - they do make sense in a way.

Cons:

- The story's pacing is actually somewhat slow. Essentially you move from one area to another, solve a set of puzzles, then move on.
- Some subtitle problems - not matching what was actually said.
- A few sound effect problems - they came slower than the actual animation.

reviewText: As close to the classic adventures as it just could be nowadays. Deep, hilarious, original, with wonderful voice acting and half a dialogues options just to crack you up laughing. Yes, there are some minor glitches and some quite unobvious solutions - but hey! That's classic too!

reviewText:
If I could marry a game developer it would be Daedalic.
Their love for the small things is without comparison.
But not only the setting is overwhelming beautiful (just by the way it's drawn). The story mixes everything they've done right in edna, the whispered world and the night of the rabbit into a perfect game and a fantastic start into a wonderful journey to deponia.
There's no better way to start a trilogy.

Lovelines: 	  9/10 (do you feel the developer's love for the game)
Creativity: 	  8/10 (is it something overwhelmingly creative)
Thrill: 		  9/10 (do you want to know how it continues)
Music:		10/10 (pays the music tribute to the game or is it just boring?)
Story:		10/10 (Does it have a story and is it great?)
Bugfree:		10/10 (Does it have any bugs? is it an enjoyable playthrough?)

Total:		9.3/10

To put it in a nutshell:
A great Adventure for rainy days ( and sunny days) and the whole trilogy is perfect for a great weekend of bingegaming.
Have a nice play

reviewText:
play hotheaded rufus, as he follows his goals to get goal's approval.

I played this point and click game before any of the Telltale games. This is the game that got me into point and click games. The game starts off really quickly, and things are explained/taught to the audience really quickly. I liked the 2D animation of this game, as well as the horizontal AND vertical movement that existed.

The humor in this game was really funny, and well done, and the cinematics were great. I found the length of this game to be just right, and the puzzles hard, but not hard enough that I had to resort to a guide.

The only downfall to this game is the price. I have been waiting and eagerly watching the other 2 Deponia games to go on sale so I can continue my story. Buy at sale price only, $20 for a point and click (that's not telltale) is ridiculous.

reviewText:
The first of the series. The beginning of the chaos and your journey into a Machinarium-like world with all the maddening puzzles included. Be aware that this is no mere logic-based puzzle game as nothing you do will make any since unless you're MacGyver.

It's an unusual love story set in a world divided by classes, or those who were left behind. The style is very similar to a painting or comic book, with semi-fluid animations and an odd soundtrack to bring it to life. This game of the series had some rough voice acting however, which improved over the next two games naturally.

You may get frustrated with some of the puzzles not making sense, it's on purpose, and I think this may have had a more negative impact on players than expected. The story and goofiness of it all helps recover the games balance though.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: This game is different from the usual point and click games. It reminded me a lot of Pajama Sam, a favorite classic PC game of mine. It's more adult based, of course, in comparison to Pajama Sam. Between the snarky comments, adult-related hints and crude comedy, there's the point and click along with the story line. The main character, Rufus, who you play, is the core of most of the comments, and much of the comedy. There's a few parts I don't agree with, like unnessary speech options that don't do anything or cause any different outcome. (Like rude, mean comments won't let you progress. It's a trial and error sort of thing, until you find the right speech option which sometimes can be conflicting with another positive comment.) It has a nice story, but many of the puzzles aren't so obvious like 'go here, do this, for this thing that you need for this 'quest' '. The game gives you a singular hint, and leaves you to it. Much of the gameplay can end up being running around in circles, trying to figure out what you're meant to be doing. Despite this, I still recommend the game for the story and comedy. I would rate the difficulty at 'moderate'. If you're good at puzzle, and point and click games, you'll probably love this game.

reviewText:
Deponia is an excellent adventure game that exudes charm and polish, even if that polish is spotty at times. I'd say this is a very approachable game that anyone can play and enjoy. The puzzles are tricky but fair, and require a lot of thinking outside the box, which is exactly what they should. I especially love how the dialogue gives hints towards what you need to do with a particular puzzle. Deponia is quirky and funny, and if you love Monkey Island you'll love this. The language is stronger than in LucasArts' adventure games, but infrequent and still on the mild side.

A few bits where Deponia could use improvement: the subtitles are occasionally mispelled, the voice acting sounds forced or awkward occasionally, and I've run into a few glitches, although nothing game-breaking.

9/10, highly recommended.

reviewText:
Great game with lives the tradition of fun point & click adeventures (Monkey Island ...).

Some parts of the puzzles are misleading. Sometimes I know what to do to solve the puzzle but the game forces me to do it in a certain illogical way. F.e. when gathering ingredients for a drink that is to be mixed in a machine it forces me to mingle them in a separate container first. Or sometimes there is not enough feedback what a certain action does.

Also big parts of the game play in the same village. Finally the game ends too much with a hint for a sequel, which I do not appreciate as a serious business model that respects gamers (at least adventures aren't too expensive these days).

That and the above puzzle flaws give the game an unpolished character. But that 's all I want to criticize here.
Really good game overall, had a lot of laughs.

8/10

reviewText:
Deponia, despite my original worries, surprised me in the most pleasant of ways, though in hindsight, maybe I'm just a sucker for point-and-click games.
Much of the charm of this title is in the sense of humour, mostly presented through dialogue, though the puzzles are no slouches either. For the sake of brevity, I'll keep from gushing, but I put forward my personal recommendation on Deponia. To speak of it more, I imagine I would spend most of my time describing what can already be seen in screenshots, or butchering the punchlines of the dozens of jokes spread throughout the game.

reviewText:
Super funny! I like the main character for being a self-absorbed jerk. It's nice not play a goodie-two-shoes for a change and I love all the sarcasm and hatred he encounters when speaking with others and how he is a derp and is often oblivious to it. I like how even when he does realize it, it doesn't stop/affect him.

This may be a spoiler but I have to say that: In the end of the game, I honestly did feel sorry for him. I mean, we don't know why he is exactly the way he is to begin with. His father left him behind, he is probably emotionally scarred. His life on Deponia doesn't work out. He knows (or at least thinks) that his dad made it to Elysium so he wants to go too. It's not like I'd enjoy living on a smelly planet either you know. Probably the fact he thinks he will leave Deponia soon, causes him not to want to put in any effort on his life or bonds on Deponia, and rather put in all his efforts into finally get Elysium. (And perhaps seeing his dad again) although it's said that his dad was apparently selfish too so whatever.

I mean I am fine with him being selfish, at least he is up front about it. In the end, every person is selfish or at least at times but they try to hide it. :P Rufus could have played himself off as not selfish and simply wanting to help Goal the entire way, and reached his actual goal in the end, but instead he was up front about his intentions in the end and also came clean which came from the heart. I can appreciate this characer for that simply because even if he may seem a jerk, at least he stays true to himself. There are plenty of people who seem to do something for another but secretly only do it for a selfish motive, no? So if you hate Rufus please go do some self-reflection. LOL

Albeit I felt sorry for Toni for having to deal with him the way he is though, I still think she is rather stupid for continueing to allow Rufus to stay in her home. I mean, does she still love him or something? If someone would live in my house and did that stuff I'd kick them out mercilessly.

Didn't really understand the charm of Goal at all, she seemed like some kind of robotic person, reminded me of Chobits (it's an anime) which I guess is nice in a sense but she was most of the time just asleep so we didn't get to know her personality at all unfortunately.

The game's puzzles were fun and combining items in your inventory was as well, although I at times couldn't figure out what to do after trying out tons of ways without any result. Thankfully there are walkthroughs on the internet but I really wished that hadn't been necesarry. The puzzles are all logical, yes, but sometimes there just isn't enough hinting towards what you could do or objects that you can use aren't really obvious, I've had several times where I moved my mouse past an item I could have picked up but it did not show it at the time.

This still didn't get in the way of me appreciating the comical aspects, settings, and character interactions in this game, so much in fact, that I recommend it to anyone who has a more dark sense of humor and doesn't get offended easily by jokes that revolve around degradation, or a characters whose considered a selfish jerk in general. :P

reviewText:
To be fair, I started this game because it had a great art style and was a point-and-click adventure (a genre I never really got into). The story ended up being more expansive than I expected at the start, and the quirky character Rufus was really relatable as I helped him towards the goal of Elysium.

This game can get really frustrating, because after you figure out most puzzles it doesn't end well for Rufus. After I'd made Rufus' rocket and hit the ship from Elysium, I had to watch him simply fall back to Deponia and continue droning on about escaping with Goal (enough to nearly make me quit the game).

Overall, Rufus is a good character with a bunch of puns and a snappy attitude. He doesn't appreciate his friends as much as he should, so most of what happens really seems to be up to his karma. I love the art style and puzzles (although they can be terribly hard), and the music is impossible to get out of your head.

reviewText: I have very mixed feelings about this game. There were some parts of the game that were genuinely funny, which was the goal of the developer of this comedy-based adventure game. There were some puzzles that were really fun and challenging. Unfortunately, there are some major problems in this game that made me consider abandoning it at several points. Some of the puzzles try to be cute and absurd rather than logical, which make them hard to solve other than trial and error. There are some puzzles where the cue to the player is not obvious enough. There are also parts of the game where it is not clear what you are supposed to do next. For example, in many adventure games if you talk to characters in the game, they will tend to point you toward your next task. The characters in Deponia will tell you tons of jokes and wierd stories (I clicked through a lot of it), but 90% of the dialog has nothing to do with helping you finish the game. There are some out-and-out bugs, including a minigame that was flat broken. I used a walk-through more for this game than any other I have ever played (that includes Myst, Riven, Siberia I/II, Machinarium, The Longest Journey, etc). The hero of the story was a little too detestable to be funny. The artwork, style, and creativity were all there for this to be an excellent game, but somehow the developers did not learn from other great games of this genre. The result is a disappointment.

reviewText:
As a big fan of adventure point-and-click games, I jumped on this one as soon as I saw it. I wholeheartedly recommend this game to all the fans of games like this.
The story isn't very exciting, but it is interesting. From time to time you will be frustrated because the things didn't go as planned even though you tried so hard with a puzzle or an annoying conversation. The main character, Rufus, will annoy you to no end with his ego tripping and, well, stupidity. You will find yourself yelling at him or mentally high-fiving him. Other characters are interesting and have stories to tell you and are very helpful. And of course, there's a love interest. The puzzles are mostly fun, although some of them you will gladly skip, which you can. If you are like me and don't have internet access often, you will be glad to know that your achievements will still be saved. Graphically-wise, the game is gorgeous, the comicbook-y style goes well with the humour-filled conversation. Voice acting is also very good.

All in all, a very good point-and-click adventure that will make you happy and angry at the same time.
